150462423.review:
This is a very simple metroidvania. However, simple does not mean bad, as Guacamelee executes many things very well.

This is a recount of my experience on hard mode. I unlocked it about a decade ago, and have only come around to 100% it recently.

Combat encounters ramp up slowly from easy peasy to rip-your-hair-out difficult. All the combat revolves around combo-ing enemies with your arsenal of moves that you slowly acquire, and it's really gratifying when you hit every part of your combo. 

Platforming is tight, responsive, and goes just as far as it needs to. Optional areas have some real challenging screens to clear, and I really enjoyed the harder levels later in the game.

Only real gripe with this game is the "humor", which is 2013 pop culture references. This humor is deeply infused with the overall story, to the point that you get your upgrades from Metroid Chozo statues and kill a boss like Bowser from the OG Super Mario.

Still, the gameplay is really fun, and really solid, so I recommend you check this one out.

150074413.review: A fun short metroidvania with a unique style and simple combat system. Worthwhile if you enjoy 2d platforming, exploration and combat. Lot's of references and easter eggs and surprisingly witty writing. Short and sweet and definitely worth your time.

149074969.review:
In a nutshell, Guacamelee is an enjoyable, colorful, metroidvania/platformer that features fun (though few) boss fights, occasional platforming and combat challenges, and a silly storyline/characters. More than ten years since its release, it has aged rather well, IMO. 

For the most part, the general gameplay is of average difficulty. This is broken up throughout the game with challenges (most are optional) that test your platforming and combat skills. If your goal is to complete them, it's not too bad, but if you want to do them with ~finesse~ (be rewarded in the game with a gold star), then they typically become much more difficult. The metroidvania aspects are well implemented in that you are rewarded with money or permanent upgrades to health or stamina for returning to areas you couldn't previously access. It's pretty obvious where you should go and when to get those rewards, so the exploration aspect isn't the biggest here. The game leans into the Mexican inspiration for the story/characters/setting and is generally bright and vibrant.

In terms of downsides, I found that sometimes combat could be annoying with a few arenas lending themselves to being stunlocked by enemies with no way to do anything but accept it and die lol. I wish there were a greater variety of enemies and waaay more boss fights (though the boss fights you do get are generally good). The map also looks like something I could create in about 20 minutes with Microsoft Paint, though this doesn't affect gameplay. 

The game took me about 17 hours to complete with 56/60 achievements. I suspect if you're just going for a run through and don't care about 100%ing areas or doing all the challenges, you can complete it in ~8-10 hours. Once you finish the game, hard mode unlocks for an additional challenge.

In summary, Guacamelee is a fun metroidvania with occasionally challenging platforming and combat. The game doesn't show its age aside from a few aspects (the map, oh god the map) and is still a joy to play today. I mostly enjoyed the game's progression/the implementation of the metroidvania aspects and the bright colors/design.

147774472.review: Very cool game... It's metroidvania 2D like Hollow Knight, but more cheerful, Mexican, faster and story rich! There are objectives shown on the map, lots of different mechanics to learn and master! You play as Luchador, but you can modify your character and buy lots of abilities, skills and improvements, traverse through forests and all kinds of areas, dimensions. You encounter skeletons in dead worlds and fight funny bosses (some of them are remourseful). Awesome, juicy, complex and productive combat! You need to act and think fast in certain situations, because of the lot of parkouring and (double) jumping. You can also save your game on mexican buffets (instead of benches like in Hollow Knight). There are hidden treasures and rewards every time you beat an arena (defeat a group of enemies in a closed cage). Each type of wall can be destroyed in a certain way. It depends on the color. Beware of spikes, krakens, giant skeletons and carnivore plants!

147765120.review:
This is one of my favorite games of all time. The fun-to-navigate maps and extremely stylized environment design, the gorgeous art direction, the absolutely crisp combat, the fun abilities that pack a punch and also allow for precise movement, the progression system, it's all pristine. This is peak Metroidvania with exquisite combat and (decently challenging at times) platforming elements. Rom Di Prisco and Peter Chapman compose a beautiful and exciting soundtrack that fits each environment like a glove. The scenario and dialogue aren't the priority at all, but there's enough to make you care for and love these characters.
The desire to complete the game fully and find every secret, and then replay it again to do it again but faster, will come ever-so naturally. There are few games that are just so. Fun. To. Play. I've replayed this at least once per year for a long time now. When I think of what a video game should be, this game always appears quickly in my thoughts.

Note about Gold and Super Turbo Championship Edition: This is my thoughts on the Gold version which many would consider inferior to Super Turbo Championship Edition, considering that version has completely new areas and a lot more content. Despite that, I personally find Gold to be a lot better paced, more challenging, and overall well-rounded. In exchange for more content, STCE has some major pace-breakers while this version is just go-go-go from beginning to end. STCE also gives you some overpowered abilities while in this version, your skills are really put to the test. Trust me, you're going to want to replay this a lot, and there wouldn't be any point in going back to Gold if you played STCE first. It's not that STCE is worse in any way, it is almost a direct upgrade in general, but I still think it's worth playing this version first.

138158085.review: Guacamelee! is simply an amazing metroidvania with a Mexican setting. The art-style has a cartoonish angular look, which may look a bit weird at first, but it fits well and establishes the game identity, since it’s immediately recognizable. It has a lot of charm and humor as well. The story is basic, with the game shining in the gameplay. To be honest, it’s nothing you haven’t seen before, but it’s well implemented. The game is fun, and the controls feel right, both in combat and platforming sections. Combat is melee focused, where you combo normal attacks, throws and specials moves. A clever design choice is that these special moves are also used in movement and are needed to access some optional areas, and in true metroidvania style, some areas aren’t accessible during your first visit. The map does a great job marking those spots, so you can easily return later when you have the necessary abilities. The soundtrack is also great. Given the setting, I was afraid it was going to be very Mexican, but to my surprise, it’s way more modern and videogamey, while still being Mexican inspired. I was humming along a lot of times. It’s also a great game to hunt 100% completion. Some optional challenges can be a bit harder, but there’s nothing hardcore in here. More importantly, it doesn’t feel like a chore. However, play the Super Turbo Championship Edition instead, which is the definitive version of the game, with more content added. Not only that, but that content is seamlessly integrated. I only played that version, and I couldn’t tell what was the original and the new content. It was all great. And there’re also more good stuff, like 4 player co-op and a Steam Workshop for custom costumes. I had a great time with this game, and it’s an easy recommendation. Definitely worth your time and money.

138103583.review:
Guacamelee! Gold Edition es un videojuego de acción y plataformas desarrollado y publicado por Drinkbox Studios. A continuación, evaluaré los aspectos de jugabilidad, apartado gráfico, apartado técnico, rejugabilidad y duración, y proporcionaré una calificación para cada uno de ellos y un promedio final.

Jugabilidad:
Guacamelee! es un juego de plataformas de desplazamiento lateral con elementos de combate. El jugador controla a Juan, un luchador que se embarca en una misión para rescatar a su amada de las garras de un villano malvado. El combate en el juego es rápido y fluido, y el jugador tiene una variedad de movimientos y habilidades para derrotar a los enemigos. Además, hay una serie de acertijos y desafíos de plataformas en el juego que agregan variedad y desafío.

Apartado gráfico:
Guacamelee! tiene un estilo visual impresionante y vibrante que utiliza una paleta de colores brillantes y diseños inspirados en la cultura mexicana. Los personajes y los enemigos están detallados y bien animados, y los fondos están llenos de detalles interesantes y coloridos.

Apartado técnico:
El juego funciona sin problemas y no tiene problemas técnicos notables. La banda sonora es excelente y complementa perfectamente el estilo visual del juego.

Rejugabilidad y duración:
Guacamelee! ofrece una duración de juego sólida, con un tiempo promedio de juego de alrededor de 6-8 horas. Además, hay varias áreas secretas y desafíos adicionales que se pueden desbloquear después de completar el juego principal. El juego también tiene un modo cooperativo local para dos jugadores que agrega aún más rejugabilidad.

Calificación:

Jugabilidad: 9/10
Apartado gráfico: 9/10
Apartado técnico: 8/10
Rejugabilidad y duración: 8/10
Promedio final: 8.5/10

En general, Guacamelee! Gold Edition es un juego de plataformas impresionante con una jugabilidad sólida, un estilo visual vibrante y una duración de juego satisfactoria. Es una gran opción para cualquier persona que busque un juego de acción y plataformas desafiante y bien diseñado.

131644917.review:
This is stretching the definition of Metroidvania. There is virtually no exploration with the exception of the endgame areas to collect orbs that don't do anything other than unlock a different ending. While you do unlock new abilities that allow you access a handful of health upgrades from previous areas, the real puirpose of the upgrades is to increase the chvariety and challenge of the next set of platforming sequences. This game is a beat 'em up platformer, not a Metroidvania.

The platforming sections are challenging and sometimes infuriating. I also can't help but feel that a large part of the challenge is the awkwardness of the default controls and the sliding, ungainly movement of the player character. The combat is actually pretty fun in most cases, though there isn't a ton of variety in terms of enemies--perhaps a dozen different enemies or so. The game was at it's best when fighting tons of enemies at once due to the clever way that many moves can be used to crowd control enemies. The constant shields and realm switching required in later combat sections were not as successful but were still mostly fun. The handful of boss fights were generally not as good as normal combat.

The art style and atmosphere of the game is a lot of fun, and the music is great.

It's also quite short, and overall I wouldn't recommend it for most players other than fans of difficult platformers. Even then Hollow Knight does a lot of the things Guacamelee is doing much better. With better controls, better boss fights, and better Metroidvania elements.

129447748.review:
Nachooooooo!

…oops, wrong Mexican!

One of the best games I've ever played. Music is incredible, fighting is terrific, and story is outstanding. I strongly (and very subjectively) disliked the art style, but the game is so good that I got past my dislike for the visuals.

Guacamelee was the first game my wife’s boyfriend ever played to completion since he was a child and he absolutely loved it. The theme, the art style, the dialogues...everything.

I really loved that Guacamelee fuses platforming and combat in a way that other Metroivanias don't quite manage.  In a lot of the classic metroid and castlevania games, different weapons and abilities open different doors or allow you to get to a new area, but this time each of your attacks is ALSO used for traversal, which is brilliant. 

I got it on sale long ago and I just liked how easy going it was in terms of the writing and art style. I loved how the combat is punchy and satisfying and seeing what different kinds of combos or strings I could pull off and since the game wasn’t very long I didn’t find it overstayed it’s welcome either.

Not to mention that it’s freaking hilarious. Seriously, if you like Metroidvanias and difficult platformers I couldn't recommend this games enough.

10/10

117567527.review:
This is one of times that I wish I could judge a game as in between recommend and don't recommend.

[b]Recommend-ish[/b]
I had fun playing this game and I like the metroidvania styled levels. It even has some references to the chozo tribe statues. It has the basic, be a hero and save the princes story line. Nothing really flashy there. The graphics and story are ok. That's the basic reason why I don't want to say I don't recommend it. It is ok and not that bad.

[b]Not Recommend-ish[/b]
As for why I don't particularly recommend it is the following. The controls. There is a delay built in when you hit enemies, assuming to let you land combo's. But dang does it get frustrating later on. At some point I dare say it is even hindering you from playing the game at times. At later levels the enemies get more difficult and they will be spamming moves which you need to dodge or counter. But the freezing makes you play it safe and not be able to execute lots of combo's. Cause if you happen to try hitting an enemy multiple times, another enemy will be spamming a dodge only move constantly.

Also they recommend you to play with a controller. I did... It doesn't work sometimes. Sometimes it felt like the buttons were not responding. And sometimes it would execute multiple button presses after each other. And the special moves it would execute were sometimes also wrong. I would press right + B button and it would perform a headbutt which is just B.

The game isn't even really that hard. But the controls made it harder than it had to be. Buy it in a sale if you must. Just look at the achievements. 17.6% of all players actually killed the last boss.. That means a lot of people did not finish the game at all. I bet it is partly because of the controls.

110067303.review:
[h1] 遊戲製作理念與技術非常成熟的小品遊戲 [/h1]

我相信很多人對這遊戲畫風不感興趣，因此選擇跳過這製作精良的小品，我原本也是如此。當時是因為完成一個rpg經典名作，感覺有點身心俱疲(:tank:)，因此想換個動作遊戲來變變口味。一開始是選惡魔獵人4，雖然手感是爽，但那移動及戰鬥時切換的視角讓我實在讓我抓狂，終於在一次要連續跳高台的關卡上，因為視角切換還有著地的判斷點跟貼圖有很大誤差，我毅然決然刪掉遊戲。在歷經身心俱疲及被不成熟的3D視角技術氣到後，決定找一款動作類的小遊戲來玩，於是我從遊戲庫中翻出這塵封多年的Guacamelee。

老實說，剛開始一點都不期待，只知道好像是平台動作遊戲，連遊戲介紹影片都沒看過，完全不知道內容是什麼。但慢慢玩下去之後，發現這居然是一個銀河戰士類的遊戲(感覺這遊戲標籤是後來才貼上去的)，從遊戲設計角度來說，他的關卡機關設計、戰鬥招式與攻擊手感、學習曲線都是設計得非常精準，其中有需要玩家利用操作技巧解謎的部分，但因為設計的非常好，玩家通常能理解關卡或敵人攻擊模式的設計邏輯，讓人不看攻略就可以一直玩下去。

首先我先講我覺得我個人最喜歡的[i]戰鬥招式與攻擊手感[/i]，尤其在玩這款遊戲之前我先被惡魔獵人4玩過了😟（希望改版的DMC不要這樣），對比之下，Guacamelee設計讓玩家會隨著時間進行，一步一步慢慢學習不同的技能及戰鬥招式，所以有惡魔成那種慢慢成長的成就感。此外，戰鬥招式及許多敵人角色攻擊模式，根本就是致敬街頭霸王及其他格鬥遊戲，例如隆/肯的昇龍拳或是惡狼傳說泰瑞的前衝波，很多招式習得後，不是只用在攻擊，在一些關卡的障礙或是平台跳躍也是一定要用到才能夠繼續前進。在每次學習到新招式時，遊戲會讓你透過關卡的設計熟悉新招式的操作，而且招式及技巧的總數量夠豐富，不會無聊，但不會多到讓人記不住。所有學習到的招式，都可以跟基礎攻擊搭配組成連段，在與敵人戰鬥時打出連段真的很爽， 而且常常不同的敵人，須要用特定不同的攻擊招式才能破解，也加強玩家對招式的運用，在我總時長不過9小時的遊玩過程，我最終BOSS戰也能擊出51連擊打趴BOSS(請參我遊戲截圖)，不過這不代表這遊戲沒挑戰性，因為我大頭目也是重打了好幾次。

另外在[i] 關卡機關設計 [/i]上，一樣會透過一步一步習得的技巧來解謎，例如潘強、二段跳、甚至後面有飛行，由於這是一款銀河戰士類遊戲，有些前期關卡障礙物無法突破的部分，也可以在習得新技能後回去再探索，挑戰每個關卡完整收集。有些機關設計可以看出在致敬其他遊戲的味道，例如傳送門，需要透過正反兩極不同的傳送點，而且後面還要搭配不同的技能與戰鬥招式組合，才有辦法通過，非常有挑戰。

設計組在[i]]學習曲線[/i]設計上也非常用心，我自己本身是手殘黨，很多關卡設計或與敵人的戰鬥，會讓你一直熟悉不同的技能與戰鬥招式，讓我也能隨心所欲打出連段，這就是玩到後來可以玩得很爽的原因。關卡設計或敵人攻擊模式，很多時候看起來無法通過，但多觀察機關設計原理或敵人的攻擊模式，就可以慢慢理解出可以搭配的技能與戰鬥招式來解決， 而且失敗後的逞罰不會很嚴重，因此很容易讓人一直挑戰，不會失敗後要花許多時間才能回到目前的進度，這點我要大力稱讚😍。我常常遇到挫折後關掉遊戲，但沒多久後又會手癢打開遊戲來解決關卡或魔王。

總之，雖然我很不愛這遊戲的畫風，但至少他畫面很乾淨，不會讓人不知道哪邊是不能踩、或看起來有路的隱形牆，雖然沒加分，但也沒扣分。其他方面如上所述，雖然是小品遊戲（我沒收集完全部要素，但要完成全部收集，我覺得不會特別難），9小時遊玩時間雖短，但很精實，可以感覺設計手法很成熟，他的續作我肯定之後也是會找來玩的。如果不是那種非3A不玩的玩家，我都非常推薦。

105511172.review:
This is really one of those games that feels odd in a few ways in terms of both how it's perceived and also how it portrays itself. First and foremost is the way that despite being touted as such a strong metroidvania experience despite not really strongly embodying a lot of the core traits that form the distinct experience that come with the genre, instead often relying on surface level comparisons without quite understanding the deeper elements of what make them work so well. A similar statement could honestly be said to the game as a whole, taking so many skeletons of ideas and implementing them in an extremely barebones, surface level way that can often feel more like a series of nods to various pastiches and series rather than its own distinct entity. Despite this however, I ended up overlooking a lot of it while playing Guacamelee, because while it might falter in a number of areas, it's often really fun to play nonetheless.

I feel that a lot of the fun this game has to offer can be found in its combat encounters and the way a lot of focus was given to make it feel as good as possible. The player might only have a few simplistic moves, but not only has everything mostly been designed to transition into all of the others smoothly, allowing the player to rack up huge combos, but every attack feels extraordinarily weighty, with this loud, bassy thump with each instance of contact made even more satisfying by how time even very subtly slows down during impact to add that extra something. This makes what is often a rather simple game in how the player approaches each encounter still feel decently engaging, which is fortunate because in a lot of ways, this game really feels a bit lackluster and is only saved by how it looks and feels in my eyes, even if these aspects are mostly handled amazingly.

While the combat might feel good, I felt like the encounter design itself felt EXTREMELY economical and rigid in how it was approached, enemies usually only having one valid way of beating them or just being damage sponges without really anything in between to lead to more dynamic action. Enemies usually have one weakness and essentially require you to exploit it, but often it's done in ways that feel very forced and cheap, especially with the yellow skeletons and the way they want you to knock them up in the air. Rather than simply being far more difficult to beat on the ground, it feels more like these enemies instantly dodge after you try hitting them a couple of times and then strike back before this pattern repeats. Not only does this make them feel very formulaic, knowing that you essentially have to play things exactly as the game wants or be subjected to something really frustrating and tedious. If instead, these enemies simply were very agile and unpredictable on the ground, this would not only provide a less intrusive method of guiding the player towards an intended solution, but it would provide more player agency by making it feel less as if the game is cheating you to force your hand.

While enemy design like this is present all over the game, it's really when the elemental shields that can only be broken by one specific attack come in that my issues with how the game handles encounters hit their worst. Integrating such an artificial way of having to deal with enemies using your arsenal significantly cheapens the experience from my perspective by not only further removing a sense of player agency, but by then utilising it in such a blatantly "gamey" way. I feel like simply colour coding special enemy behaviours could have had similar effects while providing a more dynamic, interesting element to the enemy design to bring it up to that next level. Aesthetically I also think this game works amazingly for the most part, with its cartoony atmosphere and its evocative setting both creating a game that looks and feels like no other that I've played, further backed up by that Mariachi style soundtrack to seal the deal. The issue mainly comes from the fact that while on one hand, the game handles its setting well, it then will fall extremely short through the sheer amount of times a hollow reference will be made or a meme is used, which took me out of the experience a few times when I saw stuff like "me gusta guavas" and one of the main villains going "trolololololo". It's honestly the game references that annoy me more however due to the way it almost feels as if the game is trying to say "hey, we're kinda like this game" while showing off the most simplistic, surface level comparisons like "we have powerups and gated progression too!!!".

Drive to explore the world was also very hit or miss due to the way that exploration felt so artificially gated yet again, with colour coded blocks that usually only led to a room with a treasure chest anyway. There was very little drive to actually go back and explore, not only because of the map system shouting at the right direction for the player to go, preventing a more natural sense of exploration to be found, but also that any extra loot you'd find was either a health upgrade, stamina upgrade, or money, none of which are things that mattered for the most part due to how easy the game was for the most part, deemphasising the significance of upgrades purely made for your ease of survival. The way the story and objectives were framed was also really off, with these long stretches where it felt as if the game was building up to an encounter only to go off on a tangent and kill all feeling of suspense, which ended up leading to half the game feeling like a frustrating struggle to have literally anything happen, while the 2nd half was a nonstop, anticlimactic beatdown of all the villains while you kept getting told that the main antagonist had already gone somewhere else. It sometimes felt extremely hard to get at all invested in a narrative that was paced as poorly as this.

It's a pretty big testament to how good this game actually feels to play that I had so many issues with it on such a wide array of fronts and still ended up enjoying it quite as much as I did however, as while this is in a lot of ways, a rather barebones experience that doesn't really try doing anything that impresses or excited me all that much, it's still a pretty great time if you go through it as you would a typical 2D action platformer game. The game just, FEELS great to play in a lot of respects and is also short enough to have been worth it without really wearing out its welcome either. Despite the complaints I might have made, this is totally worth getting and is probably something that a lot of other people would enjoy a bit more than me as well, I just get that vibe from this.

7/10

105178871.review:
Definitivamente se merece un puesto en los mejores indies Metroidvanias: 
Su jugabilidad Beat 'em up con scroll lateral le da una personalidad muy reconocible y muy bien lograda, donde los combos no se sienten azarosos, generando una sensación de satisfacción continua en el jugador.

Los power ups son muy clásicos, como hacerse más pequeño para poder abarcar otros lugares, romper ciertos bloques para llegar a nuevas áreas, escalar, pegarse a paredes, doble saltos, etc. Lo interesante de la mecánica de los power ups es que, a diferencia de otros videojuegos del género, absolutamente todos sirven para el combate, incluso el de cambiar del mundo de vivos a muertos, al punto de ser trascendentales para crear combos e incluso usarlos de forma obligatoria para romper escudos de ciertos enemigos, o alcanzar a los que están en el plano de los muertos.

El argumento principal, sin ser muy complejo, nos adentra en el típico "viaje del héroe" con una clara identidad de la celebración del Día de los muertos, específicamente celebrada en México, con nombres clásicos de la cultura, como Juan y Carlos, protagonista y antagonista respectivamente.
El apartado gráfico complementa la experiencia magníficamente, repleta de personalidad, con un diseño simple y caricaturesco que da colores vivos (y apagados), apuntando directamente a la celebración misma. El OST dentro de este aspecto ambienta muy bien la experiencia, haciendo uso de instrumentos referentes del género como trompetas, acordeones, guitarras rasgueadas, maracas, entre otros.

El mapeado, por su parte, diría que es el aspecto mejor trabajado; la conexión entre sectores está bien lograda, el plataformeo es desafiante y puzzlero, los secretos no están ridículamente escondidos, pues siempre hay pistas para alcanzarlos. Lo que trasciende en este apartado es el desafío y el ingenio con que cada jugador puede explorar el mapa, a través de los diversos power ups que se van consiguiendo, que, como en todo metroidvania, abren camino para nuevos secretos, nuevas zonas, y nuevos desafíos.

No menos importante son las referencias, cameos e influencias de Guacamelee. Desde referencias mecánicas como romper un puente con un hacha para eliminar a un boss, hasta la presencia de los power ups en estatuas con un huevo en la mano, contemplan un par de referencias visuales a clásicos de los videojuegos como Mario y Metroid, así también como a muchos otros (y más actuales) que simplemente parecen ser un capricho del creador para decir "oye, me gustan estos juegos", que, si se entienden, nunca están de más, y sacan una grata sonrisa.

Recomiendo altamente Guacamelee por ser un juego muy divertido, a pesar de no ser extremadamente difícil y tener un tiempo de juego bien reducido. No faltarán las risas, la entretención, la exploración, los pollos, los luchadores, los frijoles y los chiles picantes en este hermoso e ingenioso título.

103552989.review:
24.11.2021.

Game #180

[h1] Replaying a title I remember liking [/h1]

Guacamelee is one of those games I played before in the past and was both looking forward and not looking forward to playing again. Don’t get me wrong, I love this game, in fact, it’s one of the best metroidvania games I’ve ever played in my life, but, at the same time, I’ve already played it before. How interesting is it going to be to replay this game? Turns out, plenty!

[h1] A mexican Metroidvania [/h1]

Guacamelee is a game that sets you in the shoes of a Luchadore. You will play as Juan and your job is to rescue El Presidente’s daughter from an evil Esqueleto Calaca. Yeah, as you can tell the main theme of this game is: Mexico. Every single stereotype you know about Mexico is in this game: luchadores, cock-fights, tequila, sombreros, mountain goats, ancient Aztec ruins, enchiladas and let’s not forget evil esqueletos. Ummm… did I mention that I absolutely love everything about the game’s theme? I can’t get enough of all the cultural references no matter how silly they make them look. Oh and the music is just divine. I used to rock my daughter to sleep with the main town theme. I guess it also helps that the game plays really darn well.

[h1] Don’t need nothing but my fists [/h1]

Guacamelee is a 2D metroidvania game. In true metroidvania fashion, you will visit many different places where you will learn power ups and get stronger and more agile.Using these power ups, you’ll be able to progress through the game but also backtrack and find hidden treasures and collectables. Unlike most metroidvania games, this game is pure Melee (just like the title suggests). Juan does not need any whips or screw attacks to fight his way through hordes of esqueletos, just his fists, feet and nogging. Surprisingly, this works really well in the game. By combining all luchadore abilities for both combat and platforming, the developers created a truly unique, yet familiar, metroidvania game.

[h1] Tight controls and awesome power ups [/h1]

Both movement and combat feel super fluid and responsive. It’s a lot of fun in the beginning to punch your way through enemies and watch your multiplier go up. The combat is fun. A bit easy but still fun. The game tries to make you use different attack combinations so you can achieve higher scores but, you probably won’t care much about it since you can win most fights with just basic punches.
Now the power ups you get are a lot of fun. You’ll get an uppercut which will act as an extra mid-air jump, until you get a proper double jump. Then you’ll get a ground stomp, wall breakers and even an ability that will turn you into a chicken so you can fit through small spaces. 


[h1] Living world vs. Dead World [/h1]
One of the coolest features about the game is how you have both the living and the dead world. The dead world is basically a mirrored version of the living world. At first, it may seem interesting to switch between these worlds using portals but later you will learn an ability to switch worlds at will. This creates great platforming sections where platforms will only appear in one of the two worlds and you’ll have to switch between them all the time. 
Unfortunately, the game also uses this feature in combat and that leads to some really frustrating moments. Often during combat, you’ll get enemies that you can only hit in the living and those that you can only hit in the dead world. The problem is that it becomes really overwhelming to doge and switch between worlds all while avoiding everything. Nothing game breaking but still frustrating. I really didn’t care much about this.

[h1] Love Mexican culture? Love Metroidvanias? Play this game! [/h1]
Yeah, I’m totally going to recommend Guacamelee. It’s probably better to purchase the Super Turbo Championship edition https://store.steampowered.com/app/275390/Guacamelee_Super_Turbo_Championship_Edition/ since it adds a few more features but even this version is worth it. This is just an insanely fun metroidvania game that I highly recommend to anyone new and familiar with this genera. Now go and punch some Esqueletos!

Next game: Guardians of Middle Earth
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/111900?snr=1_5_9__402

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I’m trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. [/h3]
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG

99383174.review:
Original review: Great game. I love the luchador theme and attack combos.

Update: My initial review did not do this game justice.  To say I enjoy the luchador theme and attack combos is an understatement. The game is not only enjoyable to play, but  quite creative in it's artistic renditions and character depictions. If nothing else, this game serves as an interesting ode to lucha libre, mariachi and Dia del los Muertos elements of Mexican culture. The lighthearted theme and quirky (if not out-right corny) humor do not take away from the game play and- surprisingly- are not an indication of the game's difficulty. In one moment I find myself laughing at the humorous commentary and in the next, frustrated as I have failed to scale the Tule tree yet again. And for those who do find the difficulty on the easier side, the game can be played in "hard mode once beaten...or before that if you know the cheat ;)  For those who find the difficulty too challenging, I might suggest the Super Turbo Championship Edition of the game which- besides offering some extended game play options- is designed to be a little easier. I've heard from many others that there is a lot of overlap between the two, so I wouldn't recommend  buying both unless you REALLY love the game. I do think an easy mode and a few DLCs to expand game play for all difficulty levels would have been a better option than essentially recreating the same game in the STC Edition.

And then there are the attack combos which provide you with plenty of fun ways to demise your foes. I came to appreciate the game itself as a bit of a tutorial on using these special combos in unique ways: via level design and in-game practice on "Poncho".

Overall, Guacamelee is a unique and interesting game, worth the money.

91921000.review:
After being successfully explored in earlier games, DrinkBox offers us their own take on the Latin American culture and comes up with a solid production while also starting their own franchise.

- Graphism -
The inspired artistic direction is served by warm color palettes, smooth character animations and a somewhat papercraft aesthetic reminiscent of a TV cartoon and high quality Flash productions.

- Gameplay -
You quickly have to master each ability earned if you want to complete the challenging platform sequences and overwhelming fights which will eventually follow. Your skills will definitely be put to the test.

- Story -
If the plot isn't groundbreaking by any means, the colorful characters you'll encounter during your adventure, as well as the omnipresent humour and references, make interacting worth your time.

- Sound -
Latin music is cleverly mixed with Chiptune sounds and dynamically changes as you swap dimension. SFX work satisfyingly well in their context and help create a believable world to explore. 

- Replay Value -
Approximately fifteen hours are necessary to complete the adventure and unlock every remaining achievement. You might come back for speedrun purposes if the difficulty didn't turn you off.

A solid entry in the Metroidvania genre with a well-balanced mix of fighting and platforming sequences. Worth giving a shot but beware of the brutal and frustrating difficulty spikes.

A bite sized Metroidvania!  Guacamelee is pretty great.  I happen to love the Drinkbox "house style" and this game uses it very well.  Lovely 2d graphics and backgrounds.  

Guacamelee is a combat focused Metroidvania, that can be beat in 4-5 hours on your first runthrough.  It's not a bad thing though, you get many of the joys of a metroidvania without a lot of the padding or backtracking. 

This game is combat focused, and the combat is pretty good.  You don't have a ton of moves at your disposal, but what you do have is effective, and more importantly, fun.   You are given a strong dodge move, which gave the developers more freedom in making the combat difficult and exciting.  Sometimes there are a bunch of enemies with shields that need to be broken by certain special moves, and some will be in real world and some will be in the dark world and it will be too much and you will take some cheap damage.  That is my only complaint with the combat.

There are some sidequests and some arena stuff, but i think I am going to skip it and head on to the sequel.  I enjoyed my (brief) time with Guacamelee!  

8/10

82093941.review:
An interesting 2D (action) platformer. It introduces new mechanics and concepts regularly, which expands the gameplay. From unexpected abilities that allow you to traverse the map in interesting ways, to enhancements to your enemies. I don't know if I'd go as far to call this a metroidvania. I guess it qualifies, but an important aspect of that genre is the exploration of your environment and the eventual discover of the way to go. In Guacamelee there's always a marker pointing you in the right direction when you open the map, so that sense of discovery is lost. On the other hand each area of the map is so big and takes so long to traverse that it could easily become frustrating without that.

The highlight to me is clearly the combat, specifically the bosses. Fighting the jaguar guy on hard difficulty has been one of the most fun experiences I've had lately. Similarly, the rest of the bosses required some practice, and while I found myself dying often it was an enjoyable experience to eventually overcome. Outside of the bosses the combat is still quite engaging. Enemies acquire new abilities as you progress, which will require you to perform the correct action to disable them. When you have to fight multiple types of enemies, protected by different effects it can lead to a fun chaotic battle where you find yourself constantly dodging and jumping while keeping your combo active.

The platforming was basic but fun, some sections surprised me in terms of difficulty and what's required of you. Looking back my favourite aspect of the platforming is probably the black and red thorns which require you to roll or dodge in mid air. Your character controls and feels heavy, as it takes a bit of time for him to turn back in mid air. That's why I found a certain power-up way more enjoyable than the default character. 
[spoiler]And that's the chicken[/spoiler] which controls very fast and honestly I'd love to play a whole game as him.

I have mixed feelings when it comes to the visuals. When you're inside temples and areas with walls in the background it looks detailed and good. But outside of those instances the game is kind of empty and flat looking despite its colourful tone. It reminds of Super Meat Boy in the sense that it has a flash art style look to it, but unlike SMB the camera is too close to the character most of the time, which does the game a disservice when it comes to visuals.
While I didn't enjoy the look of the environments that much, I'll say that the character models look quite good and I was reminded of Disney's Aladdin at times for some reason.

I found myself skipping through the dialogue since I just wanted to play the game. I caught glimpses of the story and some references to Super Mario Bros among other games. I'd prefer to be able skip the entire of the dialogue with a simple click, like you do in Celeste, but it's still not too bad.

I found the game to be surprisingly enjoyable and I wouldn't mind purchasing the STC edition down the road to play it again.

78676043.review:
Guacamelee is my first 2D platform combat game.  The combat system is beginner-friendly, and all the key bindings are set in the correct place. You can utilize specials attack and primary attack to perform some sick-looking moves, and you can see how Lucha Libre influences within the game. However, the level of difficulty can escalate quickly if you want to get 100% achievements.  Some of these achievements really made me want to pull my hair out. 

You can see the developer pour their heart out for this game. The game graphic is enjoyable, it uses a vibrant color theme rather than realistic, which effortless ties with the Lucha Libre background. Lastly, there are so many silly jokes hidden in the game for you to discover as well.

I highly recommend this game to anyone, whether you are or are not a fan of 2D combat, this game might be just the right fit for you.

77491504.review:
Ay mi corazón! Guacamelee, I wanted to love you.

The art style, humour and incredible world drew me in, but the controls and platforming took me right out. I thought I was going to be ok with some hard platforming given that I've loved Hollow Knight, but... in HK the brutal platforming made sense since the controls are so precise, and I managed to enter a form of intuitive, hellish bliss where I died a million times but I always knew exactly how I failed, and it kept me from getting too frustrated. In Guacamelee, unfortunately, the frustration hits almost immediately, and I kept quitting even though I could've advanced story wise.

It just took the fun out of it when I was unable to get to a chest yet again because of how badly the platform/world shift mechanics combined with the clunky jumps. I kept thinking they should've implemented a simpler form of double jump, and an alternative to the awkward shoulder button mashing. I was so excited to play this too, but it feels like a huge grind for pointless rewards that has nothing to do with player skill.

77394316.review:
This is a console ported 2D platformer/brawler with a simplistic animation artstyle and a rich Mexican luchadore theme.

Often the use of this kind of art style is done because the developers are lazy or lack talent to arrange anything better, but in this case a lot of work went into it and it looks okay.  The game features excellent writing and a fun story, which really helps things along.  On the downsides, well, at heart this is still a console game and the gameplay is just a repetitive platformer/brawler with less than perfect controls, and not really well suited to KB+M.   It's worth noting the developers superseded this edition of the game withg a Super Turbo edition, but leave this on the store out of sheer greed.  That's unacceptable.

It's a shame to see good artwork and a fun story being wasted on an old, dead game format, but there's a reason these things should stay on consoles where the peasants like that kind of thing.   Also, $21.50 for a 2D platformer?  No way.

76331629.review:
This is for people with a PS4 controller. Guacamelee doesn't let you rebind controller buttons.

Imagine the game "Getting over it" where launching into the air required a specific combination of buttons on a controller. Now imagine a section of that game where you had to use the analog back shoulder buttons to swap between surfaces existing. When you press this button the surface that you just launched from disappears and the surface you are jumping to appears. So you have to press this after launching from the first surface and before hitting the second.

If you are within a wall while you press this analog shoulder button the game will auto revert back to the state before you pressed that button. Now imagine jumping from one surface where you have to press the shoulder button after jumping from one surface so that the wall in front of you disappears, Then after your jump has completely cleared the obstructing wall you press the shoulder button again before reaching the wall you need to land on. When you land on the other wall you must also be holding triangle or you will just slide off that wall, which actually requires you to hold the controller in a claw grip or stick down the button due to the other buttons you need to be pressing during this time.

Now imagine a section where you have to do but when launching from the first wall you need to use a special jump that goes really fast, but has a seemingly random delay before it suddenly kicks off. Now Imagine sometimes that middle wall isn't a wall that disappears but instead is electricity that you must dodge through with perfect timing. One small hitch... your dodge button is the second analog shoulder button.

This is "getting over it" so any mistake in this process will see you falling to the bottom of the map to start all over.

Sound like fun?

There's a bit of an imperfect fix. Basically ,while the game doesn't let you rebind controller buttons, it does allow you to rebind keyboard buttons. Steam then allows you to rebind controller buttons to map them to these keyboard buttons. So given that it's possible to make the game somewhat playable. This doesn't fix the issue with having to hold down triangle, but it at least makes these parts passable on a PS4 controller. What you can do for the triangle button is bind your spacebar to this and then put your foot on it! I have no idea why it had to be like this! 

So finally, the game itself is quite good, but it seems the devs didn't give a shit about trying this out on a PS4 controller or making the controls sensible and instead just recommend you use an xbox one. :/

The game would be sooo much better with some common sense put into the controls.

72334168.review:
Combat revolves heavily around stringing together combos. There's a sidequest that's all about practicing moves in certain orders that can be a little frustrating, but when you're actually fighting enemies, it eventually became fairly instinctual for me - pretty similar to Super Smash Bros., actually.

Progression is fairly linear with either the map telling you where to go, or there only being one path forward. The blocks to progression are nothing exciting - just different color blocks that you need to learn different special attacks to break through. For those looking to get 100% completion, the map of each area is pretty helpful in marking the location of any chest you've seen but not grabbed, and making pretty clear where there's an area you haven't explored. The overworld map also lets you know when you've gotten everything from an area.

The upgrades aren't really hidden behind puzzles, so much as platforming challenges, but these challenges usually just boil down to trying to string the right sequence of movement together without messing up.

All in all, a satisfying little action adventure game

72095712.review:
A good all-around exploration platformer aka Metroidvania. Overall, the game is simple, clean, well-crafted fun, but isn't going to blow any minds. If you're into this genre of game, I definitely think it's worth a try.

Full Review:
The combat is fast and fun, though a little on the easy side overall. Unfortunately you have to complete the game once on Normal to unlock Hard Mode, so I haven't tried it. There are some frustrating enemies and situations where it feels like you will get hit no matter what, since you are vulnerable immediately after throwing or dodging without having any options to avoid attacks that might be overlapping you. The enemy variety is a little lean (maybe 12 enemy types overall) but some additional modifiers such as shields which require you to use a specific attack to break them are enough to keep it interesting for a game of this length.

The controls and movement are good overall, but can be a little touchy when playing with a controller, causing you to sometimes activate moves accidentally or use the wrong move.

The game is fairly linear and doesn't have a lot of freedom of exploration compared to other Metroidvanias, but it makes up for this with good level design that has lots of entertaining platforming sections interspersed with combat arenas. There's a fair bit of backtracking for optional upgrades, but thankfully getting around the world isn't too tedious and it's easy to spot areas you haven't been to yet just by looking on the map. The game also helpfully includes a completion percentage for each area. 

The main game is quite short, especially if you don't go back to get everything, but there's some optional extra trials which extend the playtime a little and add some much needed challenge. Even so, getting 100% on a single playthrough won't take you more than about 10 hours, depending on how long you spend in the optional challenges.

The lightly humourous tone and aesthetics of the game are fun and very competently made, but the overuse of dated memes and references to other games makes Guacamelee feel a bit hollow in terms of presentation. I think the game would have been better overall if it tried harder to build on its own style and identity.

Although I didn't try it, this game also has fully-featured 2-player co-op which certainly improves its value for someone looking to play the game with someone else, as it is one of the only games in this genre to offer multiplayer.

71262505.review:
Guacamelee is a very stylish 2D metroidvania. Juan the (very muscly) agave farmer has his girlfriend kidnapped by Calaca, a skeleton from the world of the dead. After being summarily dispatched by the sombrero-wearing skeleton, Juan finds himself in the world of the dead. There he gets a mask that allows him to return to the world of the living as a luchador (Mexican wrestler) and fight back against Calaca and his henchmen.

This game is steeped in Mexican tropes and terrible food-based puns. Almost everything in the game is a pun, and the whole thing is wrapped in a very irreverent air. There are silly little screens that pop up before boss fights to announce who is fighting who, the character(s) make silly poses when they get new powers, your helpful wise old man guide is a goat, and one of your important upgrade powers is the ability to turn into a chicken.

Yes, it is a rather silly game.

Overall, the core gameplay is pretty straightforward for a Metroidvania – you have your basic set of attacks, a little trio of punches and kicks, and over the course of the game you gain six additional combat maneuvers, the ability to wall jump, double jump, the ability to turn into a chicken, and the ability to swap between the world of the living and the world of the dead. (And, if you complete an optional sidequest, the ability to fly in chicken form at the very end of the game)

Sometimes enemies are surrounded by a colored aura which protects them from harm, and if you want to hurt them, you have to use the proper move on them. You have to use your abilities to break some colored stones to access new areas, as well as some secrets. And of course, you use your new movement powers (including a couple of combat maneuvers) to access new areas over the course of the game.

It’s all pretty standard fare, and honestly, the game isn’t particularly innovative in any way mechanically. Honestly, the enemies aren’t particularly remarkable either; there’s not a huge number of them, and not a great variety in them, either.

Fortunately, the game is pretty short, so before it would become tedious, it’s all over, and you’ve beaten it. Just going through the game would take you five or six hours, and 100%ing it takes about nine – and the game would outstay its welcome if it was any longer than that, so that’s a good thing.

The whole game is just… done competently. It’s nothing particularly remarkable, but the style of the game works quite well, the game is silly enough without trying too hard to be lulzy, the game looks good visually, the overall core gameplay is solid enough, and it avoids the trap of being overly long.

If there is a flaw to this game, it is that it doesn’t really wow the audience in any way – if you’ve played Metroidvanias, you’ve basically played this game, and there are certainly better ones than this. But on the other hand, this is well-paced and a nicely sized experience, and it is probably above average overall within the genre – it doesn’t do anything remarkable, but what is there is done well.

In the end, I give it a thumbs up. It’s worth playing if you like Metroidvanias, and it’s small enough that it ends before you’re tired of it.

68604662.review:
This game is not bad, in fact it is wonderfully done and I would say that it is a masterpiece in its genre, my issue with it is actually its genre, it's just not properly labelled.
It's not a demanding action-platformer for the masses, it's a crazy hard game for jazz pianist.

Going through the game is quite simple enough, it's about 9 hours to get a "bad ending" (that does feel rewarding at all, not because it's sad but because it is sad AND feels undeserved in a game that's all light-hearted jokes), yet only 17 % of players seems to have make it that far. No idea how long for the good one, as the game is simply trying way too hard to do too many things to be enjoyable.

- The combo mechanic seems to be important and you have a nice (and challenging) training room where the game shows their potential, but most of the time screens are either unthreatening or on the opposite flooded with too many enemies too think about what you are actually doing.
- The bosses are quite boring and their pattern is just "dodge and hit". Literally. They attack either by jumping or rolling, hit and repeat. The way the game increases the difficulty is by making them faster and the hit window narrower (with a special mention to the last boss where it's almost impossible to bring down the whit shield between certain patterns)
- The endgame platforming is awful: a level like Treetops just ask you to be a tech death drummer able to achieve complete control over each of your fingers and it's just too much for me. Not only does it ask for really precise timings but also the management of your vertical and horizontal dashes, phase changes and special moves in a single screen. It's just too much for me, I don't feel as great after achieving such level as I felt when clearing a tight level in Super Meat Boy or  a Voodoo Mask in The Messenger's DLC. And here it's not just one tight screen, it 4 tight double-screens (this makes unlocking The Kid in SMB feels like a piece of cake).

This is a fun and enjoyable Metriodvania type of game. however, one of the MOST important aspects of a platformer  to me is TIGHT control and with the mechantics it is presented with.  For the most part, Guca has pretty decent control.  However, for one to 100% this game to get certain items with ablities  requires extreme precsion of control.  A fine example would be the Tree Stage where to get an optional item to the chest requires to you to wall jump, use your up jump ability, plus changing between dead and alive world for certain platforms to appear.
This works on paper but the way it was executed game code wise was not.  I find out that I may ONLY use the uppercut kick ONCE until I've landed on the ground, despite having enough stamnia to use it multipule times to able to accomplish the jump (bad mechantic execution of the ability) 
While I know how to solve the puzzle to get there, it is similar to "Ibb and Obb" (stay AWAY from that one!).  The control has to be very 99.95% upon executing to accomplish some of the jumps.  Let's face it. We're human. NOT a computer.

While I have yet to finish the game, I find it frustrating that games like this which likely will cause carpal tunnel of using over and over movements is just punishing to the player.  It's not challenging developers!  It should NOT have to hurt my hands just to make a series of complex jumps where as with most platformers I've played, there's more than one way to complete a goal.

Overall fun game, and certainly USE a controller when needed.  But if you are looking for precison jumping and platforming with TIGHT control, this ain't the game for you.

62603929.review:
As a disclaimer I have not finished the game. In fact I'm not entirely sure if I've even come close. Bear in mind that as of posting this I'm just past the first major boss.

Guacamelee has a lot going for it. The graphics are charming, the kitschy dated pop culture references are fairly unobtrusive (and funnier following the release of the sequel), and the combat can be really punchy and satisfying. The music is a treat, too, which perfectly complements the brisk exploration and platforming. That said, for all of these pluses, each one has an ugly side. The visuals can be rather harsh to look at, with bright, saturated colors rapidly flashing when acquiring an upgrade. Likewise, the music can be rather loud and abrasive during these moments. The pop culture references, while funny, deprive the game of its own identity. Many of the jokes and design choices are copied from the internet and other games and are merely adjusted to fit Guacamelee's art style. At my current position in the game I've encountered only one memorable joke that seemed to be original, with the rest being background visual gags that refer to dated memes. Lastly, the combat and exploration are hindered by slightly imprecise controls that seem to devour my button inputs. In addition, I think the combat could've benefited from an additional side tutorial or two to better teach the player about the mechanics, as there were several moments where I took seemingly unavoidable damage.

Overall, the game is fun, but it doesn't take itself seriously enough to meet its true potential, as bizarre as the sounds for a game full of old memes. 3/5

61720617.review:
Once again I find myself wishing that Steam had a "meh" option in addition to thumbs up or down. I'm going to have to give it a thumbs down though, because I don't recommend it. The game just has too much hostile design going on. There were way too many times that one minor change would have turned a bit of platforming from frustrating and boring to fun and challenging. It relies a lot on repetition, but poorly. Where as some games, like Super Meat Boy, throw you right back into the action, the game feels the need to pad its platforming out with busy work. This means you don't even have a chance to learn what you did wrong because by the time you get back to it you've forgotten because of all the busy work. It just makes it boring. The platforming was doable with effort, but it just didn't feel worth it after a certain point. The game is, quite simply, dull.

In the interest of fairness there were things I liked. The characters are interesting, I like that there are little side quests. I even liked backtracking into previous areas to use my new skills, and it felt like an accomplishment. The visuals are very nice, very crisp. The humor can be good at times. It has a very specific style of humor. It's hard to describe, but if you've played games like this, throw backs to older genres from smaller studios with a nice art style, you know the type. It doesn't always land, but when it does it gets a chuckle.

Overall, I would not recommend this unless you LOVE platformers. Non-hardcore platforming fans will be in for a mediocre time.

60970448.review:
Guacamelee is a game in the style of Super Metroid -- a wonderfully designed, coherent, sprawling world full of secrets, optional challenges, and fun powerups -- and it's also a fairly deep and exciting fighting game in the style of Devil May Cry. Where Metroid and DMC were often cold and scary, Guacamelee is friendly, funny, and full of fun characters. With how extreme the makeover is, you'd be forgiven for thinking it was entirely different, but make no mistake: This one has all the smartest design ideas from both of those, and it weaves them together extremely well.

First, the Metroid aspects. This game is so dense and so crystal-clear about its gates. 99.9% of areas you can't reach yet, you know why, and when you get the ability to go there, you'll know. It's just a matter of A) remembering, and B) pulling off a tough maneuver sometimes. There are multiple kinds of optional powerups, and there's coins and a store where you can unlock more. Many of the optional rewards are coins, and they're worth it. All the core upgrades are useful, unique, and exciting, not to mention versatile.

The Devil May Cry aspects work great too. I'm not a fighting game master by any means. This one feels deep enough that I know I'm nowhere near the skill ceiling. You need to chain combos and improvise them as things change, as well as avoiding attacks and using specific moves to counter certain setups. All the Metroid-style powerups you unlock are new moves, and they can be woven into combos in a ton of ways. The enemy variety isn't enormous, but each fight feels unique due to map layouts, enemy combos, and hazards. There's a side challenge that asks you to master a TON of different combos.

The game is absolutely dripping with Mexican culture, to the extent that it almost feels wrong to play it in English. It's full of jokes, most of which landed for me, and references to other video games are EVERYWHERE. You can really tell the developers are in love with gaming. The character design on display here is really strong and distinctive, and the music -- dios mio! As a purely aesthetic experience, Guacamelee is excellent.

It does have a couple of flaws. Every once in a while, the game will lock up on me. I think it's when I run past a save station and into another room, but I don't know why. And there are some sections that are too punishing for my tastes, leading to frustration. Some of the fast-travel points are placed oddly. But these are minor issues.

In summation, I've had a great time with Guacamelee. It's fun, it's tough, it's charming, it's deviously clever, and it's gorgeous. An absolute gem of a game, and one of the easiest recommendations I can make.

58921701.review:
This game has a very strong foundation. It's so strong that it almost became one of my favourite Metroid-vania games of all time. Unfortunately, the game doesn't build upon this foundation to any significant degree. In fact, it actually detracts from it and therefore ends up just being a great game rather than a fucking awesome game.

The foundation of this game is very simple. You have your 3 hit attack combo. When you hit enemies with your attacks enough time, you can "grapple" them. This grapple has 3 functions:
	• AOE attack: After you grapple an enemy, you can throw an enemy in any direction. When thrown, the enemy will knock down any other enemies in the way.
	• Attack reset: Right after you throw an enemy, you can repeat your 3 hit attack combo. Surprise surprise, most enemies can be grappled after 3 hits.
	• Invulnerability: While you're grappling an enemy, you're invulnerable to any damage. This allows you to dodge attacks and carefully aim enemies to fly in the direction you want them to.

Because of how useful the grapple is, the developers have been able to create a combo focused system witch just 2 attacks (3 hit combo and grapple). Simple and effective.

As you progress in the game, the combat slowly gets built upon using special moves. These special moves are basically heavy attacks that attack in a certain direction (up, down, left/right, stationary). These special moves ALSO reset your attacks. This is very useful for big enemies that can't be grappled. So far so good. You can use grapples to take on multiple small enemies and special moves to take on large enemies.

I thought the combat would progress to link all of these attacks together so that you would be doing really long combos while fighting many enemies all at once. That would've been really cool….. But unfortunately the enemy design stops this from happening. The small enemies' health pool is too small, so they die in like 2 combos (e.g. 3x attack --> special move ---> 3x attack = dead enemy). You can't do a long ass combo on an enemy that dies so quickly. The big enemies' don't get stunned, and they attack in the time it takes you to do 2 combos. Therefore, unless you want to take damage, you're forced to dodge and restart your combo. 

While the above is limiting, the late-game enemies are the worst. This is where the foundation of the game starts deteriorating. Late-game enemies, including bosses, automatically dodge after taking a certain # of hits in the MIDDLE of your combo. This was a really bad design decision. Note that it's the # of hits, not the damage. Therefore, combat against these enemies is all about spamming your special moves since they do the most damage per hit.  You almost never want to use your regular attacks OR grapple and so combat is actually more boring in the late game compared to the early to mid-game. Keep in mind that special moves take energy, so you'll be spamming your special moves, waiting until your energy recharges, and repeat the process.

To be fair, combat definitely becomes more challenging as the game progresses. This is because of the way fights are designed. You're not really fighting enemies 1 on 1 as you move throughout the world like in most Metroid-vania games. Instead, most fights happen in square arenas (e.g. you can be exploring and then walls appear to the left and right of you. Enemies start spawning in and you can't leave until you beat all the enemies). These arenas can have various hazards and multiple enemies can spawn in an arena, forcing you to take on multiple enemies while being wary of your surroundings. Furthermore, late game enemies have "shields", which require a very specific special move in order to break the shield. Late game enemies also have some attacks that can't be dodged, forcing you to double-jump/wall jump over them. So while YOUR attacks get more limited (i.e. you're just spamming super moves rather and not normal attacking and grappling), the enemies' attacks and defenses get more varied and interesting. I died multiple times on certain groups of enemies and got a great feeling of achievement when I beat them.

There's only 5 bosses in the game, but they're all very distinct from each other and require mastering their unique attacks. I particularly liked this boss that's 3 skeletons combined into 1. In the second phase, each skeleton covers a portion of the screen (1 in the top, 1 in the center, and 1 at the bottom). They attack with laser beams that can't be dodged, and always attack 2 at a time. In order to dodge them, you need to use your super moves to stay in the 1 portion of the screen that the skeleton is not attacking. This was a great way to make "spamming super moves" an interesting affair and I wish all of the bosses and enemies made spamming super moves as interesting as this. 

While the combat gets slightly stale near the end, thankfully the platforming stays engaging throughout the game. This is some of the best platforming I've seen in any 2-D game. Your character can wall jump and double-jump. Also, the special moves are worked into the platforming since the move that makes you attack up is effectively another jump, and the move that makes you go left/right is crucial for certain platforming sections. Furthermore, your character can dimension swap between 2 dimensions. In 1 dimension there are certain obstacles/platforms while in another dimension they're different. Swapping between these dimension quickly when platforming is crucial to succeeding, and it made the platforming sections so satisfying to beat.

The progression system is well done. Beating enemies awards you currency which you can use to buy stuff at checkpoints. You can buy health ups, energy ups, costumes, etc… You can also find health ups and energy ups in chests while exploring. There are a LOT of chests to scattered throughout the world, so it's always rewarding to go off the beaten path and explore. So you're rewarded for adventuring, so that's fun.

There's a story that's fairly typical. A villain kidnaps a girl and you as the main hero have to save her. What's not so typical are the characters themselves and their dialogue. This game doesn't take itself too seriously and the characters can be genuinely hilarious sometimes. They have unique personalities and there's a lot of pop culture references. There's a scene straight from Star Wars in one scene and I laughed out loud when I saw it. 

Overall, this is a great game with a very strong early game. It's unfortunate that the late game was not as engaging, but what's here is still a great package.

56706714.review:
TL;DR  ~~~This is the best game I have played in a long long time.~~~


Well there's probably not much left to say about Guacamelee! that hasn't already been said.  It's a six year old game but as is so often the case, the old ones are the good ones.

I'll keep this short; I put 42 hours into this game.  One play through on normal campaign and then again on hard mode.  I also 100%ed both runs, so yeah that takes some time.  With all that time spent, I figure I'm a credible source when I tell you this is one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played.

Everything about the game is slick.

Graphics and animation are beautiful and buttery smooth.  Seriously, the overall art style is just awesome and playing this on the big screen is a lot like watching a very action packed cartoon.

The sound effects are great and the music is quite simply brilliant.  Kudos to the guys behind the OST; the fact that every area has two versions of its thematic music is such a good idea.  One of those subtle little things that is so well handled it takes a while for you to notice just how well implemented it is.

Thematically the game never misses; everything just fits into the world.  The lore is rich but lighthearted.  There is a wonderful sense of humour in all aspects of the story and the gameplay.  

The pacing is absolutely perfect, and each new skill arrives just as you have mastered the previous abilities.

It's a metroidvania based on Mexican culture, and the land of the dead plays a significant part.  It is colourful, it is fast paced, it is responsive and you feel like the baddest of all bada$$es by the time you deliver the final blows to the final boss.

Seriously, I cannot believe it took me so long to get round to playing this game.  it is practically perfect in every way.  Unless you are looking for a FPS or a strategy game, in which case you will still probably enjoy this game more.

Thanks to DrinkBox Studios for absolutely nailing it.

I will play Guacamelee! 2 once all this joy and wonder settles down.

49527148.review:
This is a neat combination of metroidvania and beat-em-up with a Mexican luchador and day of the dead theme with plenty of humor and tongue-in-cheek references to other franchises (especially Super Metroid).

However, the game does have a few flaws. Foremost is the controls. Many of the attacks and special abilities require you to tilt the stick and press a button, but a disconcertingly large portion of the time it registers the wrong direction. Given the relatively high difficulty of some parts of this game, this can be incredibly frustrating when your character does a side dash instead of an uppercut to gain altitude while platforming (or vice versa), causing you to fall to your death and have to repeat a sometimes lengthy section. Same thing goes for combat, to defeat some enemies you'll need to throw them, but the throws go completely the wrong direction about half the time.

The second flaw is that the overall difficulty is honestly too high to really be fun for a general audience, especially since there isn't a difficulty slider. Near the end of the game many of the fights end up like bullet hells with screens full of projectiles and shielded enemies (which you can't hurt unless you use the correct special power to break the shield first) and enemies in multiple dimensions which can hurt you regardless of what dimension they're in, but you have to be in the correct dimension to hurt them. On top of that, enemy attacks ALWAYS stagger you. Your attacks do not always stagger enemies. Not all enemy attacks can be dodged. Not Cool, especially combined with the sometimes flaky controls.

However, this isn't the main reason I don't recommend this game. The real reason is that there's another version of it, the Guacamelee Super Turbo Edition that's the actual definitive version of this game, which I do tentatively recommend getting (even just to play through the first 90% of the game before the difficulty wall). I have no idea why the devs left this obsolete version up to confuse people, or why they didn't upgrade everyone who had older versions of the game to that improved version. Big thumbs down for mismanaging multiple versions of the game.

49198667.review:
[I]Guacamelee[/i] is a nicely done Metroidvania-style game based all around mexican and Lucha Libre culture (I'm a big wrestling fan, so probably this last aspect was the main reason why I decided to play it). I'll say all the things I found good about the game first:

- The artistic side as a whole. Both visuals and sound. The game looks spectacularly beautiful with it's simple colorful style. It looks exactly how Dia de los muertos and Lucha libre look in my head when I see them mentioned. And regarding the soundtrack, again, it sounds like I'd think Mexico sounds, with its songs based on tradicional Mariachi music. I think it does an amazing job respecting and honoring the whole culture they went to base the game around.
- This might fall into the artistic side too, but I think it's worth a special mention how incredibly great the animations of Juan, our protagonist, are. EVERYTHING he does is 100% Lucha libre. He runs like a luchador, jumps like a luchador, kicks, punches, headbutts exactly like a luchador. I absolutely LOVE the amount of detail they added regarding that aspect of the game.

With that being said, I'll touch upon the not so great parts for me:

- The story. I get that the story of the game is meant to be rather simple and straight to the point as it was on classic videogames like Super Mario Bros., but that's not exactly what I'm criticising. The story really glows in the very beginning (Until Juan becomes a luchador) and in the very end, but on that time you spend in between it doesn't feel like they give you much of a story to keep you motivated to keep playing. It feels pretty linear in a "Go there, do that, defeat this" kind of way. I would've loved if they added more cutscenes throughout to maybe give some background to the secondary characters you encounter through the adventure.
- The difficulty curve. I don't know if it was just me, but to me it felt like the game was pretty easy until the last 2 boss fights. At that point it feels like it goes from 0 (Or maybe say 25) to 100 incredibly quickly. This helps to give a whole climax feeling to the very last part of the game, but it made those 2 last boss fights difficult to the not-so-fun frustrating side, and even though it was entertaining I'd prefer if the difficulty curve didn't go so steep there.

All in all, I recommend playing it. It is a gorgeously looking and sounding game, with plenty of entertainment to offer and some end-game content for the more completionists.

8'25/10

47569584.review:
I really thought I was going to like Guacemelee, with it often being cited as one of the best modern metroidvanias. After having beaten the main story and having no desire to complete any further, it seems to me like a fairly average game let down by some unfortunate design choices. Got a lot to say so buckle up.

Platforming is a disappointment, plain and simple. Everything is way too floaty, and with no ledge grab you'll be missing platforms by frustratingly small amounts quite often. The powerups you get (various dashes and slams in different directions) seem like they would help with platforming, but they affect your momentum in such an unhelpful way that they often feel really bad to use for navigation.

Combat is great at first. The slowdown is fantastic, the combos, the throw mechanic, it's really really fun. But it's only when you get later on in the game and things start to get more difficult that the cracks show. For one thing, the "shields" they introduce - where you have to use a certain powerup direction to break it in order to damage the enemy - are a good idea on paper, but are used way too often in the late game. When the gauntlets start introducing enemies of all different shields, some requiring a dimension-swap as well, combat becomes a nightmare of trying to hit the special move, using the wrong special move, missing enemies, being hit, the shield regenerating, being hit, being hit. Oh yeah, let's talk about that.

Fuck me. Whenever you take damage, you are THROWN backwards and start falling, with absolutely NO air control possible. You'll fall for as long as it takes to hit the ground, and you can do absolutely nothing during this time. This is the single worst aspect of the game for me, and the appearance of projectile enemies (who have a nasty habit of showing up in some later platforming sections, where any damage taken could knock you down with no chance at angling yourself better) make things all the more worse.

A minor nitpicky factor is whenever you get a powerup, or complete an upgrade, there's this splash screen that VERY quickly flashes yellow, pink and blue. Yeah, they weren't kidding about the seizure warning in the beginning. I'm not epileptic, but I could barely look at these screens, they are absolutely abysmal. As far as I know these were removed with the Super Turbo Championship Edition, but apparently that version has its own issues.

I really don't like giving games thumbs-down, especially for ones as well-renowned as this, but I felt it needs to be said that this is absolutely NOT the masterpiece that people give it credit for. Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of positives here too. The game is light-hearted and tongue-in-cheek, the story is decently entertaining, going back through older areas is always a joy in these types of games, and combat is fun - at least for a while.

Guacamelee is a few hours of fun, and you will likely come away satisfied, but the frustrating aspects soured my personal experience just a little bit too much for me to recommend.

46519035.review:
If you've ever been interested in the Metroidvania genre, brawler-beat-'em-ups, Central and Southern American heritage, or wanted to play a REALLY good game at a reasonable cost, then Guacamelee is the game for you.
Although released nearly 6 years ago at the time of this review, its unique artstyle, responsive controls, engaging if archetypal characters make a gaming experience truly like no other.
My only criticism for the time being is that it can be a bit confusing to decide which version is the quintessential version for those just experiencing it. And, although I loved my experience with the Gold version, I've learned that significant critical improvements have been made in STCE edition and in its sequel that make this game something of an inferior model, but its all still the same wonderful experience.

This is not my final verdict on the game, but as it stands, finishing the campaign twicr and beating a significant portion of the El Infierno challenges, this game is soundly the best I've played in years. It's a shame it took me so long to play it.
