44965866.review:
Sensational platformer. 

Guacamelee has  a great sense of humour, awesome mariachi-eque music, a vibrant visual style, and a very well pitched difficulty level. I had a tonne of fun with this. The nifty finger work required to get past certain sections of the game challenged my dexterity to the max in the style of Super Meatboy, and the melee combat is highly enjoyable. I love how the game reveals its world to you slowly but surely, and you gradually get powers that give you the ability to access different parts of the gameworld, and  that everything fits together in such a neat way. The polish on this game is first rate, and the vibe is just so good: so very warm and endearing. 

Has that elusive "one more play" feeling. Loved it! 

(also made me hungry)

44879095.review:
Saludos, debo decir primero que nada que le he dedicado de verdad muchísimo tiempo a este videojuego, y que en general suelo hacer eso con cada uno los títulos que han pasado por mis manos, ya que creo que para dar una opinión bien fundamentada es necesario explotar al máximo todo lo que pueda ofrecerte, en mi caso ya luego de más de 60 horas de juego puedo decir que lo jugado lo suficiente para dar una buena opinión al respecto.
Con respecto a la jugabilidad todo al rededor de ella esta muy bien pulido, los comobos, el esquivar, los ataques especiales todo se siente parte de un todo, muy bien llevado y que inclusive habiéndolo jugado sólo con teclado te proporciona una experiencia mucho más que satisfactoria, las mecánicas de cambiar entre el mundo de los vivos y el de los muertos para acceder a lugares que de ninguna otra forma se hubiese podido, lo rejugable del titulo, la vidillida adicional que le dan los logros y misiones secundarias no de una forma forzada sino que se siente complementaria, y por supuesto su gran abanico de referencias que te sacan una sonrisa y hacen del juego algo mucho más personal y especial a mi parecer.
Aquí no vas a encontrar cosas súper estereotipadas que hacen quedar mal a la cultura de la que se sirve para crear todo un mundo donde la magia, las luchas y los tacos están a la orden del día.
Guacamelee! sin lugar a dudas ha superado todas mis expectativas, un juego mucho más recomendable me atrevería a decir que es indispensable para cualquier amante de los metroidvania, o plataformeros en general.
PD: No me lo creo que existan persones que le critiquen por "no poderse jugar sin mando" cuando puedes personalizar los controles como los sientas más cómodo, además de que siempre responden realmente bien.

44332979.review:
There’s something so delightful about DrinkBox Studios’ unbridled passion for luchador wrestling. Most of us can appreciate mostly-naked men in masks fighting one another, but DrinkBox takes it a step further with [i]Guacamelee(!)[/i], a Metroidvania brawling platformer hybrid set in a fantastical world of Mexican folklore. As farmer-turned-luchador Juan, we’re tasked with leaving our hometown on a quest to save the President’s daughter from the evil [strike]Osmund Saddler[/strike] Carlos Calaca, a skeleton man in a big hat with ambitions to merge the world of the living with that of the dead.

To this end, we’re traversing a series of large, branching levels in search of new abilities for Juan S. Kennedy’s arsenal, most of which enable movement in a different direction. This is what helps [i]Guacamelee[/i] stand out from the often bland and irritating Metroidvania genre: progress comes both from unlocking new abilities and mastering the usage of them. There are genuinely good platforming elements at play here, and while the combat can be a jankfest in large fights, it’s a game that, for the most part, plays really well. This (and all the funny [i]Resident Evil 4[/i] references you can make when talking about it (did you see them before? God, I love myself)) elevate [i]Guacamelee[/i] to the status of what real reviewers would call ‘a love letter to games themselves’, and what I call ‘a really really excellent game’. Chaining dashes and uppercuts in midair to reach new heights is exhilarating, and one of the later boss fights felt more like an actual ‘fight’ than any I’ve previously seen.

Aside from this, [i]Guacamelee[/i]’s crucial issue is that it can’t decide whether you should be using the thumbstick or directional pad to play it. The pad allows you to accurately pull off the different attacks, but when grappling you need to aim with the stick to actually get enemies where you want them. Swapping between them wasn’t a problem, but chaining attacks with the d-pad was, and the now-permanent dent in my left thumb will always be there to remind me of what a delightful game this otherwise is. Short and sweet (the game, not the thumb-dent), it has a clear goal and attains it, ramping up the challenge and variety more and more until it abruptly ends in a fashion that many TV shows could learn from - that is, before it loses its momentum. The restraint is to be respected in an indie market where the cool thing to do is promise the world and then work and work and work until you realise that your goal was unreasonable and you’ve been forced to compromise on a vision that wouldn’t have been that good even if realised, but even more respectable is the sheer quality of the game itself. It’s sharp-witted, brilliantly paced and uniquely stylish in ways that make it stand out for all the right reasons.

44242274.review:
[h1] The Metroidvania Review[/h1]

[url=https://metroidvaniareview.com/2018/08/18/guacamelee-gold-edition/] Scored Summary[/url] |  |                          [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/30503887/] Subscribe to our Curator	[/url]

[b]How Metroidvania is it?[/b]
Medium Fit – The brawler style combat, higher emphasis on difficult platforming and more linear design make it a different animal than the genre’s namesake games. That said, [i]Guacamelee![/i]  is something of a standard for Metroidvania game design in the Indie scene. 

[url= https://steamcommunity.com/groups/MetroidvaniaReview/discussions/1/1743346190291074544/] Want to hear a different opinion, or want to share your own review? Check out our Forum here.[/url]
 
[h1]Full Review[/h1]
[i]Epilepsy Warning - this game contains a lot of flashing screens.[/i]  

If [i]Super Metroid[/i] and [i]Symphony of the Night[/i] are the Grandfathers of the Metroidvania genre, then [i]Guacamelee![/i]  is the Abuelo of the Metroidvania indie scene. I have often seen it brought up in developer interviews with the creators of Metroidvania games, and in many ways I think its success was a catalyst for the great Metroidvania renaissance we’re experiencing now. While I think some aspects of this Gold Edition are holding it back from being as timeless as the classics that came before it, I believe I can report that its accolades are well deserved. Any of the gripes I have about this game are potentially resolved in the [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/275390/Guacamelee_Super_Turbo_Championship_Edition/] Super Turbo Championship Edition[/url] – in fact I know that a couple of my complaints are addressed. However, Gold is the version I decided to try in preparation for the release of [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/534550/Guacamelee_2/] Guacamelee! 2[/url] three days from when this review is posted, since I think it gives me the closest experience to the original game that was released and subsequently praised in 2012. 

The story of [i]Guacamelee![/i] is pretty typical. Shy man likes girl, shy girl likes man, they decide to meet somewhere, and then some jerk with the powers of a devil decides to kidnap the girl and brutally murder the shy man. Of course in a world where the line between the land of the living and the land of the dead grows thin, and the tools of deus ex machina are literally on display in the town square, murder just isn’t enough to keep a Luchador down. 

As soon as the game gets going, it’s like a fiesta from start to finish. The brawler combat is stylish and fun, rewarding combos in a fashion similar to other titles in the brawler genre. The object of each fight is to get your enemy into a stun state so that you’re allowed to grapple and toss the poor sap in any direction you please. This gives you a projectile against the ever increasing hordes of the villain Calcuta’s goons and deliciously delivers the fantasy of being a Luchador superhero. On the normal difficulty – which is the only difficulty available before you beat the game or use a cheat code – it’s all pretty easy, only getting more challenging later as gimmicks are added – or with bosses that heavily punish being hit. Most of the time button mashing is enough, but that doesn’t stop a more skilled player from really enjoying the deep combos that are possible and racking up a high score. This is made twice as fun if you bring a friend and take advantage of the local co-op feature, because when you throw a victim, your friend can catch it and continue the combo. For the combat, I’d say the game is best played as a multiplayer game. 

The game’s other challenge though isn’t as good with friends. [i]Guacamelee![/i] is a slightly rare example of a Metroidvania that also includes insane platforming challenges – rivaling games like Super Meat Boy - as a contemporary example. These are some of the most fun parts of the game, if you’re a challenge seeking type of person, but it’s also representative of some of the most frustrating design as well. At a certain point in the game you get a power that makes platforms appear and disappear, and unfortunately if you’re playing co-op like I was, this means that in the harder sections one player simply has to sit out. The chaos of controlling the platforms is just too much for unpracticed players to do in tandem. However, some of that chaos extends to single player as well. [i]Guacamelee![/i] is a game with a lot of ambition, and I think it’s mostly successful in achieving its unique combination of brawler mechanics and hardcore platforming. But it comes at a price. Some games that came later that attempt the same level of platforming goodness, like [i]Ori and the Blind Forest[/i] and [i]Hollow Knight[/i], manage to keep a relatively simple control scheme and still provide a good challenge for the player. Having fewer buttons – more versatile functions – allows the player to adapt more quickly to achieve intentionality, and thus a feeling that the game is hard, but fair. [i]Guacamelee![/i] has you using basically every button on the standard Dualshock/Xbox 360 controller. I did eventually “git gud” at it, but it was a headache to wrap my mind around some of the Simon Says style challenges, and often the issue of my execution wasn’t timing or not knowing what to do, but rather that I simply hit the wrong button out of the 7 relevant buttons to choose from. It’s completely my fault, and I don’t consider it [i]bad[/i] game design per se. It’s a minor complaint, because even with the complexity learning to play correctly is rewarded with some great feats to accomplish, but it’s also an obstacle players have to overcome that perhaps could have been handled with a little more finesse. 

The other nitpick I have probably has more to do with the game’s age and budget when it was released, but the presentation is a bit inconsistent. Some animations are absolutely fantastic, especially when it's an important scene in the story. The main town is beautifully detailed, even if a lot of those details are filled with dated memes. But, some of the monsters seem to have less care put into them, shifting to basic shapes when they attack, or feeling relatively stiff animation by comparison. And some areas unfortunately lose that ever important sense of place, breaking the immersion and feeling more “gamey” than if it were more detailed and polished. There is a propensity of areas that feel more like the prototype of a level – the layout of the challenges are cobbled together by rectangular tiles representing platforms rather than walls or tree branches depending on the theme of the area. I appreciate that [i]Guacamelee![/i] put the gameplay first, since the other extreme of this problem is that I can’t tell the platform from the background. But one of the things that makes Super Metroid so timeless is that each area feels like it could be part of the abandoned planet Zebes. I lost that feeling often in [i]Guacamelee![/i]. 

But none of these gripes hold [i]Guacamelee! Gold Edition[/i] back from being great. Far from it. I still think this game deserves the praise it’s been given. The “Metroidvania” aspect is more guided and linear than others in the genre, but backtracking lets you unlock some of the game’s best platforming feats – sort of like discovering a secret level in Meatboy. The story is simple, but it has soul. Most of all though, it’s fun as heck once you get the hang of it.  

The [i]Super Turbo Championship Edition[/i] is probably your better bet for the value, but if you want to turn time back just a little further and see what the hype was all about you can’t go wrong with the gold edition. If you enjoy brawlers that are all about scoring high combos, as well as difficult platforming – [i]Guacamelee![/i] combines the two with a respectable level of elegance. 

4 out of 5

This game is great, Although it's not a very ambitious project, it's put together very well. 

The visuals and music are good, but probably the combat mechanics and how your character progresses learning new tricks are its best aspects. I also liked the number of different enemies (although it's not that big, enemies evolve too, becoming tougher) and the boss battles, which are as hard as they need to be. 

You can add up to 3 more players to your party, what's brings the additional fun. I played with my girlfriend and we have a great time. 

Unfortunately, it relies a lot on the comical element and if you don't speak Spanish (and if you're not familiar with Mexican slang) you'll miss much of the fun.

44100865.review:
At the time of writing this, this is my absolute favorite metroid-vania themed game.
-It's easy to pick up and play.
-The combat is fantastic, attacks feel like they have weight to them and dodging attacks is super satisfying.
-The music has a great mix between traditional mariachi with a combination of electronic and chiptune. It sounds weird but it really does flow well together. 
-Workshop support to create and download custom outfits for your luchador, as well as unlockable outfits and abilities in-game.
-And just the overall charm. The art, visuals, music and gameplay really flow well together.

However for every positive there's a negative.
-This game has some seriously bad epileptic seizure problems. If you are epileptic I highly recommend staying away from this game.
-This other point will come off as nitpicking but, this game is full of extremely dated memes. They're not even avoidable and they're everywhere. Missions, background art, dialogue you name it.

With that said those cons are not the reason I'm giving this game a negative review. The real reason is because [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/275390/Guacamelee_Super_Turbo_Championship_Edition/]Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition[/url] is an outright better version of this game. Every positive I've mentioned has been expanded upon and amplified and both of the cons I've mentioned were addressed. This version is simply outdated and there's no real reason to get this version.

43330523.review:
[b][url=https://i.imgur.com/jy19hV9.gif]10/10 would spam dodge button a la DBZ again.[/url][/b]

Engaging game mechanics. Some of them are as follows that stands out from other platformers: Done-right brawler combat system and dimension swapping for the exploration part. The kind of metroid-vania platformer game that will never get too boring to play even AFTER finishing it for the first time. I have to admit something though, I didn't play this clean-handed, and by that, 20% of my [u]first[/u] gameplay was a result for looking at the Steam Guides in terms of secret discoveries. [spoiler]The first ending I got was the good one, too, thanks to the Mask Orbs. At the time I watched the bad ending after finishing the game, I cried... knowing how the Mask was the one keeping Juan alive until he removed it to meet the deceased lover at the Dead World. Was just... man.[/spoiler]

Story tells of an Agave farmer becoming a luchador after being killed by Calaca - the Ruler of the Dead World - to save El Presidente's daughter from Calaca's plan in merging the Living World and the Dead World. Story progression is clear, with humors here and there, except when plot gets obviously serious. Going back from previous area is always an option, as you'll unlock The game has 5 hours of completion (checking YouTube search bar, speedrunners were even able to finish in less than an hour in any%), without the challenges presence. Else in my personal experience, with all the golds, it'd be 17 hours. Worth. 17 hours of my life to get that one, sweet achievement. [i]Yes for some reason getting all the achievements engages me in gaming and I'm glad this is my first perfect game according to Steam XD[/i]

Graphics-wise, I'm always a sucker when it comes to Flash-based art style. When I was looking at the game files due to boredom, apparently it comes with [url=https://i.imgur.com/5YyybTv.png]free main characters sprite animation samples[/url] (:O!!!). If you have Adobe Flash CS6 (maybe lower version is possible as long as it's compatible for Actionscript 3.0), you can see how the frames and the animations are done, as you'd notice they do use most of tweening tricks there and a bit of frame-by-frame technique (I assume either they did them graciously, or they had to convert the tweens into keyframes so they could remove unnecessary frames). Yeah, a bit of warning, it won't be that pleasing for hand-drawn animation seekers, as in some cases the animation post-attack back to idle/stance doesn't have proper transition, making it look slightly jumpy, but that's really about it (this comes from an animator/animation enthusiast, not an expert). I don't have major problem with hitboxes, controls are responsive, too. [i]says the one that completed the game with keyboard, it's kind of hellish without controller but no problema~![/i]

Speaking of the achievements, there are 60 of them in total, in which are divided into 4 categories; Wooden-framed (general-the most common achievement type), Bronze-framed, Silver-framed, and Gold-framed (rarest achievement type). In my assumption, there might be a very thin boundary for Wooden achievements' difficulty compared to bronze-silver-gold ones, as some are gotten from plot-wise (e.g. "Become a Luchador" just a few minutes after you progress XD), some others are from doing one specific thing that you can change in-game freely (e.g. "I Feel Empty" where you need to [spoiler]switch your costume into The Skeleton and collect health orbs, berry simple[/spoiler]), OR the more extreme one, the "Catch The Rainbow" achievement where you have to combine all the rainbows without touching the ground - this was the last Wooden achievement I got due to harder circumstance it had to fulfill since I got way stronger near endgame). The challenges and secrets are, well, worth the challenge. Could be annoying in some of the levels if you're a gold-seeker, but thankfully manageable the more you try. That is something I can praise in this game.

Music-wise, they're actually implementing Mexican-based folklore, with most of the names being derrived from there. I can't exactly judge how the cultural adaptation was done (I can see the sombreros and Mexican music style - or maybe Spanish too - just fine), but some music got successfully stuck in my list for a while. Living World and Dead World have their own music - but stil in similar tone, Dead World one has more daunting, shivery kind of style while Living World is full of happy tone and "beat" - that will change in-sync as you swap dimensions without losing the flow in that certain ongoing music. The only thing I feel bothersome at is how the final boss music is just the more beat-y version of the normal boss music. Not that I was expecting anything, but the difference was just way too subtle. Wasn't really affecting my gameplay in general, so I gave that a pass. [spoiler]another spoiler alert, when you master SFX analyzing, you can notice the bosses' grunts before executing a certain attack. This was mostly noticed in the very final boss, instead of focusing the movements, I used this SFX-recognition the most to anticipate their attacks. Legit helpful.[/spoiler]

Misc.: Fair amount of game references. Check the posters, don't miss them.

Overall, Guacamelee! provided one of best experiences in metroid-vania platformer genre from nearly every aspects. Definitely looking forward to Guacamelee! 2. I already got pleased by tons of chickens they will have there. I bid the devs the best luck, you might get another buyer here when the sale got crazy, as I managed to get this game, the soundtrack, AND the Super Turbo Championship edition in less than $1 in celebration of Drinkbox anniversary. Great deal. :D

43261740.review: Muy buen metroidvania. Estetica brillante y muy buena jugabilidad

43180942.review:
[h1]  Guacamelee Is a metroidvania with great combat, excellent platforming, and lots of heart. [/h1]

It's fantastic to see a mexican/mesoamerican inspired game all done lovingly so. Juan is an agave farmer whose village is attacked by the evil Calaca and his love interest (the daughter of el presidente) is kidnapped, Juan is killed then resurrected to rescue his beloved and bring justice. 

You will see plenty of papel picado, fight calacas, be greeted with fanciful horn flares and mariachi music, fight Alebrijes and Jaguar warriors. The music is a sincere taste of Mexico fitted for a luchador metroidvania.

Outside of the setting and art the game delivers on every front. Combat is fast, simple and with some curve ball enemies . The platforming can get pretty tough . It’s important to note that if you are in a co-op run and things get dicey, one player can safely enter a little floating buble while the remaining player jumps/fights on. The exploration and secrest are a perfect length, that add more flavor to the adventure. It’s fun, it’s humorous, original and endearing.

Bueno, hace poco acabé este juego (Historia), que la verdad me ha gustado bastante jugablemente, la historia también está bastante bien y sin duda es un juego muy aconsejable para todo amante de los juegos 2D, y este es uno muy especial.

La ambientación personalmente no me gusta mucho, está bastante bien pero no es del todo de mi gusto, la historia está bien, ya que lo que principalmente nos mantendrá será su gran jugabilidad donde mezcla hack and slash con una difícil jugabilidad plataformera, al igual que encontrar todos los coleccionables puede llevarnos bastante tiempo. 

Que no los asuste todo lo que dije anteriormente en cuanto a dificultad, a mí en lo personal me ha encantado la dificultad del juego, no es tan difícil pero tampoco es nada fácil (Estrategia). Donde si podremos pasar un momento mal es en las zonas secundarias que nos encontremos donde habrá cofres y normalmente requerirán bastante esfuerzo superar la zona de plataformas o combates que nos pondrá a prueba antes de llegar al cofre.

Gráficamente es un juego 2D, como pueden imaginar no es mucho gráficamente, sin embargo la ambientación y el hecho de ser sandbox le da un plus.

Sonido: El sonido solo sirve para los efectos y la banda sonora, voces no hay ya que será todo por texto, es una pena pero la banda sonora y los efectos tampoco es que destaquen mucho por lo que es una pena.

Innovador obviamente lo es, no todos los días se suelen ver juegos así donde en un juego 2D mezclan elementos Hack and Slash, plataformas difíciles y todo siendo un sandbox con muchas zonas que explorar.

+Los elementos combinados entre comabates y plataformas
+El hecho de que sea Sandbox, sobre todo siendo un juego 2D
+La dificultad

-Multijugador en pantalla compartida (Hubiera sido mejor que fuera Multijugador en línea)
-La ambientación (depende de los gustos)
-La banda sonora


Sinopsis: Como manda la tradición, un año más los habitantes de Pueblucho trabajan afanosamente por tenerlo todo a punto para la celebración del Día de los Muertos. Pero, ¡oh,qué desgracia!, la alegría y el jolgorio propia de esta festividad se ha visto truncada por la invasión de un ejército de cadavéricas criaturas de ultratumba, que han emergido del Más Allá bajo las órdenes del malvado Carlos Calaca. Un villano que no contento con fastidiar a los vivos con sus maquiavélicos planes de conquista, también ha secuestrado con intenciones nada halagüeñas a la chica que quita el sueño a nuestro protagonista, el fortachón Juan. Afrenta lo suficientemente grave como para llevar a este héroe improvisado hasta la mismísima tierra de los muertos, donde deberá probar su valía frente a toda clase de peligros.



10/10

Aesthetically amazing action platformer that mixes Metroidvania with stylish melee combat.

I personally used an Xbox 360 controller, and to be honest the directional movement never felt quite as tight as I'd want it to be. Tried switching back and forth between analog stick and D-pad, and both had their own unique problems: the stick felt less responsive, but the D-pad tended to register unintional input. Still, it's completely servicable 99% of the time.

El Presidente's Daughter, the damsel in distress, being the (afaik) only unnamed major character in the game makes me wonder if the devs were aiming at satirizing the trope, but if they did... they only really succeeded in replicating it.

Complaints aside, Guacamelee was a fun game. I'm pretty sure I got bored with it when I stopped playing the first time, but as I picked it up again this past week I'm not sure why, because I had a blast!

41777930.review:
Nunca pensé en una idea tan original como la que me he encontrado en [b]Guacamelee![/b]: ¿un Castletoid con un luchador de lucha libre mejicano?. Increible.

Somos Juan, un lucahdor semiprofesional que vive en un pequeño pueblo llamado Pueblucho. La hija de nuestro patrón es secuestrada y llevada a la dimensión de los muertos. ¡Hala!, ya tenemos trabajo. 

[b]DrinkBox Studios[/b] nos ofrece un genial [b]Castletoid[/b] en el que deberemos ir adquiriendo habilidades para acceder a nuevas zonas hasta dar con el jefe final, como un buen exponente del género. Andamos entre el mundo de los muertos y los vivos, utilizando esta habilidad para superar puzzles, conseguir premios, descubrir secretos o incluso repartir ensaladas de leches. Los combates interdimensionales han sido todo un acierto.

Lo interesante de [b]Guacamelee![/b], tadavía más si cabe, es la temática y la mecánica de juego. Los chicos de [b]DrinkBox[/b] las han construido en torno a combates de lucha libre, [b]¡y resulta maravilloso![/b]. Encadenarás golpe tras golpe hasta acabar con tus enemigos, e irás a buscar más incautos a los que partir el espiñazo. No te cansarás. La música del juego, a cargo de [b]Rom Di Prisco[/b] y [b]Peter Chapman[/b], es igualmente original. Un trabajo excelente y una parada obligatoria si, como a mí, te apasionan este tipo de juegos.

Si vas a jugar a [b]Guacamelee![/b], pásate por [b]Steam Workshop[/b] y vístete como el [b]Chapulín Colorado[/b]. ¡Síganme los buenos!.

41608835.review:
I'm late to the party on this one but Guacamelee! is a fun metroidvania which sadly I ignored for quite some time. With the release of its sequel coming soon, I decided to give it a try. 

The story is not its forte; you're a luchador, which is sorta a hero in Mexic, on a quest to save the damsel in distress and saving the world. Its fun and thats all that matters in this particual game. Theres also some cool and funny easter eggs that you can find throught the game. 

Gameplay is as you'd expect melee metroidvania combat. You have a set of skills which you can aquire through the game that also unlock new places to visit. Its fun most of the times and considering the game is short, it doesnt overstay its welcome with repetitivenes. Theres also some platforming involved as expected, that offers quite a variety of fun though sadly it never expands on it. For example you have a portal mechanic which only appears in very late game and doesnt do much but could've had huge potential to expand the game a lot among other features which you'll find quite interesting. You can upgrade some skills and as you'd expect from a metroidvania game, theres lots of secrets, treasures and upgrades to be found. You can also play the game with a friend if you wish which could make the game a lot more fun.

Sound design is overall good but the soundtrack is especially well done. Fits well with the game. 

Overall Guacamelee! is good and fun game and I fully recommend it. I'm now excited for its sequel. 8.5/10

Gran juego con temática de luchadores, basado en la cultura de México, más específicamente en el día de los muertos.

Guacamelee! es un metroidvania con una gran banda sonora, momentos divertidos y muchas, pero muchas referencias a videojuegos y memes. Quizás lo único malo que le veo es que es un poco corto, y que no cuenta con multijugador en línea pero supongo que así nos evitamos el problema de tener lag, lo cual me recuerda que es un juego de bajos requisitos, y créanme cuando les digo que corre en gráficos máximos en la tostadora que tengo de pc, pero pasando al tema de la corta duración, Guacamelee! cuenta con varios logros y desafíos que ayudan a extender la vida del juego, incluso al pasar el modo historia por primera ves se nos desbloquea el modo difícil, y si eso no es suficiente para ti, la Super Turbo Championship Edition, al igual que la Gold Edition la puedes encontrar muy barata en rebajas.

tl;dr: Amazing game but YOU SHOULD STILL BUY the Turbo Championship Edition instead.

I loved this game, I'm a sucker for Metroid-vania styled games and this one is pretty sweet, the combat system is one of the best i've seen, there are many different ways to start combos (and to end them) and it's pretty fun and rewarding to experiment.

The story is nothing special, typical "bad guy kidnaps princess and wants to destroy the world", but the setting is quite compelling, the levels are very well done, the art style is simple but charming, you might like it as much as I did if you don't mind the blatant stereotypes about Mexican culture (I'm Mexican heh), also, the soundtrack is good, it's not mindblowing but it does the job.

A 2D action-platformer game inspired on Mexican traditions and folklore.

38158365.review:
I enjoyed every moment spent in this game. The way they introduced new game mechanics was brilliant. First, you would start without anything but your movement with your joystick. Then you would play as you learned all the basic stuff. After a while you would get used to those basic movements. You could see these weird colored bricks laying around and wonder what they meant. You could clearly see there is some weird holes around the map, you can't surely fit in those. What is the reason for them being there? I really didn't care about those, but thought to myself, what would happen to me, as the player, so that I could fit in those holes. The holes were small and narrow paths leading to somewhere. I knew that I could reach those places at sometime, later in the game. Those colored bricks had some meaning too. I knew it. But I could only play the game and figure out that as the game progressed.

The melee moves blended nicely with the super attack moves. The fighting was versatile. You could grab the enemies and throw them back at themselves. I think this was too powerful move, but I only learned how big of a role it was until I was closing to the end of the game. The attacks had very nice combos aswell. You could basically combo everything what you had learned in the game previously. It was nice. Everything had its balance of course. Nothing too silly. Enemies and the ways they came were tough.

The platforming, jumping and puzzles were in my opinion very good. The puzzles were in the form of jumping in the right time and changing the dimensions which you could switch. You had multiple buttons you had to press simultaneously and in a clever order. It was hard at sometimes to figure what you had to do in a certain cituations. It was nice.

The game got good and fun story telling. There were tutorials hidden besides it. Everything went smoothly. I wasn't bored at any time. The game kept me moving the whole time. I beat the game again on hard difficulty and did all the steam achievements. It was a great game and haven't played those in a while.

38127526.review:
Guacamelee is a Metroidvania-style game with a strong emphasis on platforming and brawling. As with other games in this genre, you have some freedom to explore the world, with access to new areas controlled by gaining new abilities. Exploring this beautiful Mexican art inspired world is made easy with the game's great map system and fast travel points. Blocked areas that require specific abilities to enter are color coded and are marked on the map making them easy to go back to once you have the ability to break them.

The platforming sections are mostly challenging. You'll be combining precision jumping, special moves, roll/dodge, and switching worlds to reach distant platforms. The combat provides a good challenge as well, and as a luchador you will punch and grapple your way through different enemy types that you'll be facing in bunches. As you go deeper in the game, these enemies will have different types of shields requiring a certain type of move to break. Some will also exist in one world or the other and you must be in the correct world to attack them. 

It took me around 8 hours to finish this in my first playthrough, but there's some replay value to it as you can play as other characters with different attributes. There are also some side quests, collectibles, and you can continue exploring the world after you've beaten the final boss. Highly recommended.

38116514.review: One of the best platform 2D ever!

38115794.review:
[h1]Summary[/h1]

You control Juan Aguacate, a farmer that is in love with the president's daughter of a small village in Mexico. However the skeleton Carlos Calaca kidnaps the president daughter and kills you. Luckily Tostada gives Juan a mask that revives and turns him into a powerful mexican wrestler. It's up to you to save the president's daughter.

This is a decent light hearted metroidvania game that focus mainly on platforming and brawling. If you're into these kinds of games you may want to check it out.

+ Good overall artistic and game design
+ Fun game with Nintendo, Valve and meme references
+ Not frustrating but can get challenging if you want
+ Power ups and fun to use
- Controls are kind of stiff

[h1]Review[/h1]

While you do start at a village and there are others around these are very small and only add a few additional quests. Don't get annoyed if the first village bothers you. This game focus mainly on 2D plaforming and fighting. This is not a game that makes you repeat whole sections over and over again just to beat a hard part. When you die or fall of a cliff you return to a nearby spot. For constrast the game can get difficult is in some sections were you have to either figure out a puzzle or have enough skill to beat it. It's not a very frustating game if you only stick to the required parts of the game. The extra challenges on the other hand can get frustating but we'll get to that later.

This game as a lot of Nintendo references like Mario, Castlevania, Metroid and of some others games like Portal. It's a often a funny game. The characters have their own distinguishable personalities and may be memorable to you. My favorite is the fireball head cowboy. The sections of the game also have they're own distinguishable characteristics and unique challenges. The main theme is Mexican culture based and is very well mixed into everything. The artists and level designers did a good job in this game.

Being a metroidvania game there are section of the game that require you to have a power ups in order to progress. It is however very obvious when you need these powers. You never really get stuck wondering what to do next. The powers make sense and are fun to use. The game also features shops were you can buy abilities and costumes. The abilities give you something extra to make the game easier. The costumes give you traits that have both pros and cons. For example there's a costume that gives you powerful throws but weak melee. These won't make you over powered but do give you an edge in some parts of the game and are required in some challenged.

To sum up this is a fun game that isn't very hard to figure out but it does have some small issues. The biggest issue is that the controls are kind of stiff. It's not really bad but it's noticable and that can get frustrating in hard sections of the game. To add salt to the wound, altough the game is smooth, there are sometimes unexplainable micro hickups. Could just be my PC though. Who knows? Both are very small issues but prevelant during the entire game. Other than that the first village music can get annoying but it's only temporary.

If you are up to platforming and brawling challenges this game has got you covered. However be prepared because some of these can be very frustrating, especially due to the stiff controls. For completionists [spoiler]it's not hard to get everything. You can get to any part of the level any time you want[/spoiler].

If you like metroidvania games this is a game for you.

37620560.review:
I heard about Guacamelee when Donald Mustard was on the IGN Unfiltered podcast with Ryan McCaffrey. I had just finished Shadow Complex for the first time and was thirsty for another game in the same vein. Guacamelee delivered on this note and then some. It's one of my favorite platformers I have ever played, and there is just so much it does right. You play as Juan, an aspiring and then realized Luchador, who has to save the girl and save the world. It is set in Mexico during the Dia De Los Muertos festivities and does a great job setting the scene. 

I played the Gold edition, before finding out that Super Turbo Championship edition is about the same thing but a little newer and polished. This is info I wish I knew beforehand, but I loved the game so much that I am sure I will make time in the future to run through the newer edition. You can play co op, although I never did personally during my playthrough. If you had someone dedicated to play I can see how it would be very helpful in some situations. There are tons of great character skins for the Gold edition (Nacho Libre, Shovel Knight, The Tick, etc.) and I did see a thread on steam about how to transfer them over to Super Turbo Championship Edition, if you are wishing you had all your great old skins for the new version.

So in my books for what it's worth, Guacamelee is one of the best at what it does all time. It's difficult (prepare to rage quit), it's got a story that draws you in, it has layers of functionality in the controller scheme, and it ties all of this together in a way that just really works and keeps you hooked until the end. I remember thinking while playing the second to last boss, "there's no way it can get harder than that". I was certainly wron about that, but it doesn't push you away to the point that it seems Unreachable, you get better and it runs very smoothly when you get your pacing. 



For more video game news & reviews be sure to follow the blog & follow on instagram & twitter @SublimeReviews or just follow my blog at http://www.sublimereviews.wordpress.com

34830732.review:
Seeing how this is DrinkBox's second game under their belt is pretty astonishing, the game has so much polish and well-made backgrounds along with character animations. Triple A devs should take note from these guys because they could learn a lot. The game may have flashy and colorful characters however the story is a bit lacking, with the cliche save the princess plot. Thankfully I was invested into the gameplay myself. 

The combat system is one of the best parts of the game, punching and comboing enemies to rack up combo points felt really fun. The level designs are done in a Metroid style with backtracking and exploring of each map. You progress your character by unlocking special moves that can help you make it to new locations that you could not get to before or find chest that you could not reach earlier.

Though the game is well made from a technical standpoint, there are a few issues I had with this version of the game. For starters, I wish there was a way to assign the buttons I wanted on the controller. Mashing down the roll button every nano second on my Logitech controller was not fun and having to mash the trigger to swap worlds for certain sections was a pain int he butt, however, the issue was minor and not game halting in any way.

A second major issue I found with this version of the game was pretty badly designed platform sections where you have to hop from one to another while they vanish semi random locations. You have no idea where to jump due to all the troll dummy platforms cluttering the screen that pop in and out of vision. In the Turbo edition of the game, I believe this is fixed, but it confuses me how they could not simply patch this version of the game as well.

Combat in hard mode is completely unbalanced at many sections, leaving you unable to land any hits on the enemy due to the sheer amount of spam all over the place. Literally impossible to do anything, you'll need luck in hopes that enemies will give you a window to breathe to at least take one or two out. Take that and then apply multi hit shielding and you have yourself a pain in the ass. Again I believe a lot of these sections were fixed in Turbo, why they didn't patch it into this game, no clue.

In conclusion I would indeed recommend this game if you are a fan of classic Metroid/Castlevania style platformers, however, I can only recommend the re-release as it fixes a lot of cumbersome issues facing the Gold Edition. DrinkBox Studios shows that they are competent, passionate and talented which makes them one of my fave indie devs in my books, can't wait for their next title.

Las referencias a otros juegos y el juego cooperativo le dan un plus al titulo, lo unico negativo que podria mencionar es su historia pero al no tomarse tan enserio a si mismo, queda en un segundo plano, sin duda un juego que no debe pasar desapercibido y vale cada centavo que pagues por el (Recomiendo Mando para explotar al maximo el sistema de combate).

32167328.review:
This is a Metroidvania where fighting game style combat is a significant part of gameplay.  It contains much of the standard "get upgrade, find where to use it" gameplay, but also knowing how to properly dispatch your opponents with the right moves and combos is important to your success, with the option to play solo or cooperatively!  It has a steady difficulty progression, and the game works hard to constantly provide you with unique moments.

That isn't to mention the game's humor.  It has laugh out loud moments hidden in the background, and throughout the main game.  Really, it is an excellent game beginning to end, definitely pick this one up.

31985473.review: A metroidvania style beat-em-up game that has everything I love about platformers. There is a combo system if you really want to get good at the game, but simply butting mashing is more than enough to make it through the game. The controls are very fluid and responsive with levels built for you to naturally fly through them. The game is packed with references and easter eggs, and the humor will keep you laughing the entire playthrough. This game is a masterpiece of the genre and a must-play for any fan of metroidvania titles.

30725390.review: Not gonna lie, I am not a big fan of the metroidvania genre but this game somehow got me hooked. I think it was mostly because it was a well paced game, it didn't feel either too long or too short, I managed to beat it in about 5 hours but with some extras left that'll probably bump up to about 10 hours. The combat is like marmite, you either love it or hate it. Some find it clunky and others like me find it smooth and fluid. I don't think its the combat itself but rather the animations. Soundtrack is amazing, it really immerses you within the world. I think the best feature of this game is that you can switch between the world of the living and the dead and the style changes dramatically between the two, reminds me a lot of Giana Twisted Dreams, if you enjoy that give this a go and vice versa. Would highly recommend this game.

29796709.review: A fantastic Metroidvania game with direct references to Metroid. 29793900.review:
Es un Metroidvania, con una jugabilidad bastante entretenida al estilo de la vieja escuela, nos ponemos en el papel de Juan Aguacate, quien es asesinado por el villano del juego Carlos Calaca, pero poco después y por azares del destino regresa al mundo de los vivos como “El Luchador” quien tendrá como misión rescatar a la hija del presidente.

Centrado el arte del videojuego en el folklore mexicano a más de uno le sacará una sonrisa ver todo tipo de monstruos y criaturas que son propios del mismo, además de eso el juego cuenta con muchísimas referencias a otros videojuegos de la vieja escuela que seguramente ayudaron a la creación de este genial título, tales como son: Megaman, Metroid, The Legend Of Zelda, Street Fighter, entre otros.

Por el apartado gráfico no batallamos, es sencillamente espectacular y colorido en todos y cada uno de sus niveles, si te gustan los buenos juegos de acción, plataformas y un poco de exploración, sin duda alguna Guacamelee es tu mejor opción

El combate no esta mal, cumple

La historia es normalita.

Los controles son pesimos, responden fatal, estan muy mal pensados y los puzzles de saltos son de los peores que he visto en mi vida. 

Lo mejor del juego? La ambientacion, la musica y el aspecto artistico, todo lo demas es demasiado mediocre. Si te lo pillas o que sea en un humble bundle o muy muy barato.

29592686.review:
Guacamelee is pure platforming pleasure and perfection. It's fun, stylised and quirky nature shine continuously. It starts off completely accessible and then slowly spirals into higher and higher difficulties by adding new mechanics and scenarios. In the early game you are forgiven for some sloppiness, buy the end game you must be a diety of precision. 

I really loved this game thoroughly. Highly recommended for people who like old school side scrolling games, an increasing skill curve, ultimately to be challenged, style and charisma in their games, perfect control mechanics, firm but fair solutions based platforming, and occasionally turning into a chicken. 

Not recommeded for anyone who like hand holding, infinte tutorial prompts, pay to win, one button to win, right click to win, and enjoy endless runners. This is a real bred in the bone platformer.

29389936.review:
Drinkbox released an enhanced version of this game as "Super Turbo Championship Edition". That version is Windows-only, so only buy this Gold Edition if you're a Mac or Linux user.

In addition to that, there are some serious issues with Xbox pad controls which can't be customized (only keyboard controls can). I don't think my thumbs are that fat but on several occasions the player is forced to hold the Y button to grab, then while holding Y, move and hold the left stick, jump with A and mid-air tap a left shoulder button. I don't know about you but I can't perform that while holing the controller regularly and have to resort to a cramp-inducing grip involving placing both my right thumb and index finger on the front-facing buttons, while placing the ring finger on the shoulder button.

Luckily that grip is not used all the time, so playing the game is otherwise fun but man, that's such an unnecessary inconvenience. No clue if the Championship Edition fixed that. No way I'm paying the full price again just to find out.

29016337.review:
Controles absurdamente configurados para hacer multitasking.
¡Ahora entiendo por qué al iniciar dice que recomiendan el mando! Jugar con teclado es una tortura absoluta y pareciera que en lugar de un plataformas estás jugando al p*to twister con las manos.

Además, el juego no se ayuda cuando el diseño de niveles exige una precisión tal en cierta zonas que no puedes equivocarte por un milimetro. Y es que es tremendamente jodido por el hecho de que necesitas interactuar tan directamente con el escenario, alternando entre plataformas en "dos realidades" mientras ejecutas otros 3 comandos.

Cosas como esas manchan otros apartados tan buenos como lo son los gráficos y la estética general del juego, la musica, e incluso la historia que te cuentan mientras avanzas en la partida. Y es mas triste porque para su genero es una propuesta muy interesante.

27692657.review:
[h1]¡Ay, caramba![/h1]
I’ve played the original Guacamelee! and now the Gold Edition as well. Both games were fantastic, but as expected, the Gold Edition had more to offer. Guacamelee! is a combination of a beat ‘em up and metroidvania, and boy is it a spectacular combination. 

[h1]Positive:[/h1]
- Fantastic fighting/combo mechanics.
- Very well designed dodge mechanic.
- Large variety of abilities that are fun to use.
- Immaculate control scheme for fighting and platforming.
- Very fair difficulty scaling.
- Exploration is fun and rewarding.
- Very well designed maps.
- Interesting side quests and funny NPCs.
- Nice music and visuals.
- Great use of Mexican influences.
- Many video game references made into luchador posters.
- Co-op makes it a more pleasant experience. 
- Plenty of fighting challenges to keep you sharp.
- El Infierno offers even more exciting challenges. 
- Unlock costumes that provide both buffs and debuffs at the same time (good game balancing).

[h1]Negative:[/h1]
- Not sure if they fixed the co-op dimension swapping issue in this version (if one person presses the switch button, you both switch). Can be frustrating if you don’t coordinate well with your partner.
- I wish Guacamelee! was longer.
- When will a sequel come out?
- You should probably get the Super Turbo Championship Edition.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
Guacamelee! is one of a kind. A truly enjoyable experience, one that I wish I could relive. I have 100%’ed this game and would do it again gladly. [b]A must buy.[/b]

26203280.review:
This is really hard for me.  This game has charm, fun references to famous classics, beautiful art, interesting gameplay ideas and it belongs to one of my favorite genres (Metroidvania).  But for the life of me, I just can't recommend it.  See the gameplay time I have on record?  I can assure you, without any shadow of a doubt, that more than half of it has been spent losing and retrying.  This game starts great, but at some point it becomes brutally difficult.

Now, being fair here, the basic portion of the game is easy enough.  The game only becomes harder when you try to find extras and complete challenges.  You might say I shouldn't complain then, but see... this is a Metroidvania.  Its entire premise as a genre is to make exploration fun.  And this game turns exploration into an exercise in maddening frustration.  This should be the best part of the game, and instead it's so bad in comparison to the rest that you'd swear this game started as two different ones that at some point were mashed together for whatever unexplained reason.

See, the more you advance the more abilities you unlock.  That's par for the course for the genre, and it's one of the most fun parts of these games.  The problem is that, unlike for all the other games in the genre, all your abilities are available at the same time.  That might seem like a good thing at first, except that now you're forced to remember an alarmingly large amount of special moves, because the game will force you to juggle many abilities at the same time to advance through many areas, which becomes even worse when you have to deal with Super Meat Boy -like scenery.

I mean, a game like Super Meat Boy is fun because while it offers a challenge it relies on the simplicity of the controls.  Here you have to deal with the challenge while mastering an increasingly complex set of moves.  This becomes frustrating really fast and it's exacerbated by the fact that the controls are not particularly responsive.  Push Up and the game will do Left instead.  That's not a problem in the middle of walking, but it's definitely a problem when you're trying to do a special move and the game does a different one instead, which will happen half of the time.

I can't help but think that most of the positive reviews come from people who don't try to explore in the game, or that never actually bothered to try and finish it.  Or people that have lots of free time so they don't care how much they lose.  Looking at the game's stats, I think it's quite telling that barely over 15% of the people have defeated the last boss.  Clearly most people are giving up way earlier.

I have to be as fair as I can here.  Yes, I had a lot of fun with the game, but the frustration has severely trumped it.  That's why I can't recommend it, unless you're either unemployed with lots and lots of time to waste and nothing else to play.

26099053.review:
So I was playing Salt and Sancruary and then decided to take a break with something a little more colourful and light-hearted. This is the story about me desperately trying to love Guacamelee but in the end ragequitting and uninstalling the game altogether just before the last two bosses.
I rate it positive because I hope you, whoever you are, are just better than me in platformers of this sort. Probably, I was just not up to the challenge or whatever.
I have both the original and Turbo Championship but decided to start from the original to be able to appreciate the improvements of Turbo Championship. If I ever want to play this again, that is.
I love the game's artstyle, although the colour-flashing when acquiring a new ability makes me slightly uncomfortable despite having no prior history of seizures or epilepsy. Music doesn't get too repetitive and adds to the overall character of the game. The story is simple but fun, I don't have any particular complaints about any of that stuff.
To the juicy parts now. Mechanics. I am fairly experienced with platformers and metroidvanias of different sorts and I'm not even that bad at them. Certainly, not a pro, but not that bad either. But the platforming elemets of Guacamelee made me ragequit more times than with any other game in my whole life. I think, it's because precision of the platforming is not high enough, Even after some time you cannot really estimate whether you'd be able to reach that platform with the double jump or you'd have to use the uppercut. Sometimes you reach a platform and sometimes you don't - even if it is one and the same spot and you perform exactly one and the same jump. I have to admit, I am spoilt by Ori and the Blind Forest that for me has what can be called ideal platforming where you just jump and you know for certain what the outcome will be. 
The inconsistency of Guacamelee was killing me more than anything else. You can jump and reach the platform just slightly - and the game just pulls you up and you're fine. Another time you most certainly reach it but the game is like NOPE and you go all the way down the Tule Tree. Between-the-worlds mechanic is actually very cool as an idea but combine it with inconsistency and lack of precision - and it's just hell. You have to press every button in a very certain fracture of a second or start again from the bottom. By the way, the hitbox of spikes is ridiculous. I would prefer them to have been drawn bigger to see the danger for sure than to be impaled by their invisible extensions.
For the amount of actions that have to be performed in a tight sequence, the game is not very responsive and can ignore your button pushing fairly often. When you have to go like jump-jump again-charge-uppercut to, let's say, reach another platform, be prepared that your uppercut, although pushed correctly, can be just ignored by the game or performed too late. So you have to start again. 
The sheer amount of my frustration was unfathomable. The first game ever I ragequitted every single time after a short session. I struggled for like 5 hours and decided that since it does not make me happy and it's not fun anymore but a tedious frustrating ordeal where you have to try certain sections over and over again because the game is like 'whatever, this time you didn't reach', I uninstalled it dispite being so close to the end. Then I went on YouTube and watched a playthrough to discover that you can reach the True Ending only if you found every piece of a certain item. Also sacrificed your mental health, your soul and 3 controllers, apparently. Nope, thanks.
I wanted to love this game so much but I just couldn't. At the same time I don't want to rate it negative because I think the game has a lot of work put into it and for some people it certainly works the way it's supposed to. Since Steam does not have 'neutral', I'll rate it positive.
Good luck with playing. I'm off to play Salt and Sanctuary as something more light-hearted.

25518576.review:
Guacamelee is a fun 2D adventure platforming game with different fighting moves and a variety of enemies and bosses. The game is very heavily based on Mexican culture. You play as Juan, a luchador fighter. He is trying to rescue the president’s daughter who he also is in love with. Across your travels you’ll unlock different fighting moves that also double as a different way to get around the levels. This also allows you to get to certain chests to increase your health and stamina meters. 

Gameplay is fairly straightforward. Advance through the levels and locations while fighting off enemies and the occasional boss. It will take some time to get used to using all of your attacks but the more fluid you get, the quicker you can kill the enemies. You are also searching for life and stamina chests that are scattered around the levels. Getting 3 of each will grant you a boost in health of stamina. 

The characters and NPC’s are all well done. Even though there is no voice acting in the game, each character had their own voice in my head. They are fleshed out well enough for this type of game. The NPC’s may also contain side quests. The dialog is well done and is pretty tongue in cheek. 

Graphics and music are unique. The art style of the game is very minimalistic and extremely colorful. They nailed the Mexican feel they were going for. 

[b]Using a controller is a must[/b]. You’ll be fumbling around on the keyboard very quickly. 

Controls are generally ok, but probably is one of my few gripes with the game. They seem floaty and unpredictable at times. Platforming with narrow areas to jump on really shows this. I feel they could have been tighter.

Two other gripes deal with fighting. First is the recovery time after getting hit. It’s too short and can lead to some combo attacks from the enemies that feels cheap. Second, certain enemies seem to deal way too much damage. (The enemy with multiple swords comes to mind)

[b]Pros[/b]
+Visuals and music
+Solid 60fps
+Combat system
+Mexican culture

[b]Cons[/b]
+Imprecise controls
+Recovery time from getting hit

This is a solid platformer. The awesome Mexican based environments, visuals, music and characters really makes this stand out. 

[b]7/10[/b] Good

25417028.review:
The last Metroidvania game I played (not saying which, as it doesn't matter in this review) left an egregiously terrible first impression of the genre for me. Afterwards, my friend's like "Check out this game" and I'm like "oh, great. Another Metroidvania game." So I picked it up on sale, deciding to give it a try to see whether I'd enjoy it or just quickly get a refund.

In short, I don't think I'm ever gonna ask for a refund for Guacamelee. 

When playing this game, I noticed many things that the developers did right about this game that makes it a fair and enjoyable experience to play. For example, when you get a new move to use, the tutorial goat (it makes sense in context) briefly explains the buttons and how it works, then the immediate surroundings provide a safe environment to practice the application of said move before applying it - as well as other moves you've learned prior - to traverse whatever map/dungeon/etc you're going through, as well as using the move in combat. The game does everything in its power to adequately prepare you for the upcoming trials it will throw at you while refusing to hold your hand. That, to me, is excellent game design.

The combat is based around comboing enemies, and you can even throw enemies into enemies to continue your combo; not once do I ever feel like I'm button mashing, and after seeing what sort of ludicrous combo I've done (shown in the top right) as well as the game rewarding you for such things, it just feels like I'm kicking ass all the time.

Another thing that makes Guacamelee stand out is the reference to other games (as well as memes) scattered about in the background, and even in the NPC dialogue. Inclusion of such passive easter eggs definitely add to the game's overall enjoyability. The soundtrack is dynamic (and fantastic), the map's puzzles are very clever and well-thought out, and there's many a bilingual bonus for those (like me) who have studied and/or speak Spanish, although I'd like to stress that you can completely enjoy this game without knowing any Spanish at all.

In conclusion, Guacamelee is very well designed, immersive and entertaining to play. I would like to point out that a controller is recommended (I use an Xbox 360 Afterglow USB controller and it works just fine), but keyboard controls can be remapped to whatever you desire.

This is a beautiful, brilliant game. Tight controls and gameplay that blends skill and puzzle challenges. Engaging visuals, responsive and rewarding combat, exciting original music, and cute references to Mexican culture. Be aware though, this is not a game with an emphasis on narrative. The story is a bit cliche, but for me it didn't get in the way of the experience as a whole. The weakness of the narrative is more than compensated for by the beautiful artwork and hilariously engaging characters. Be prepared to be frustrated, puzzled, and delighted by the joy that is Guacamelee.

------------

[h1]Breakdown:[/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
-Very original art style and setting
-If you are the completionist type, you will enjoy finding the many hidden treasure chests and side quests, and the metroidvania style play.
-Challenging, skill-based action
-Both new and classic puzzle mechanisms, used artfully in puzzles that will make you think

[b]Cons:[/b]
-If strong narrative is a must for you, then this might not be your cup of tea

------------

If you are like me, you will love this game. It is my all-time favorite platformer, well worth $15, and a steal at any lower price.

23759388.review:
Guacamelee! Gold Edition is gorgeous. It's interesting. It's full of pop culture references. It's polished. It's rewarding. It's [b]fun[/b]. But most of all, it's [i]challenging[/i], in both good and bad ways.

I'm not usually interested in [i]or any good at[/i] brawling games where hit combos are the focus and often the key to victory. I gave up on Arkham Asylum for those reasons. But Guacamelee!'s combat system is relatively easy to learn, remember, and execute (with a gamepad), even as more and more depth is added. The game made me work to, ahem, "get good," and my fingers definitely imprinted some muscle memories onto my brain, but it was worth the mental and digital effort. Beating the marrow out of skeletons is fun! Dying a dozen times at the hands of the same boss can be frustrating, but figuring out the attack patterns and necessary reactions and finally [b]beating the bad guy[/b] is so... [i]satisfying[/i]. And scoring large combos, while not absolutely necessary for victory, provided me with more upgrade money and therefore incentive to play thoughtfully. I felt less like I was mashing buttons and more like I had a plan, even if I didn't always carry it out perfectly.

The game does a great job of acclamating the player to the additional combat and platforming mechanics that are introduced as the story is told. I was happy to fail in the face of [i]and then adapt to[/i] the new challenges. But by the end of the game I had hit my own personal skill ceiling. If you're more skilled than me, well, carry on, my wayward agave farmer, but I had had enough.

The combat and platforming involved in the main story is of moderate difficulty, but some of the optional platforming puzzles and combat challenges are tedious and frustrating, if not almost impossible, especially near the end of the game. While I had failed earlier platforming challenges 30+ times but kept plugging away until I succeeded, I simply gave up on many of the later challenges, particularly in the tree tops and the hallways of hell.

I'm typically a completionist when it comes to achievements, secrets, unlocks, etc., in video games. Like collectable pocket monsters, I want to get them all if I can, even if it takes a large amount of time and effort. But not this time. Sure, revisiting areas to explore previously inaccessible nooks was worth my time. It was enjoyable to do what I couldn't do before. But I'm simply not skilled or patient enough to attain a 100% completion rating.

Guacamelee! broke my will and spirit. It taught me my limits. But it also taught me I could be successful while playing a 2D brawling platformer. No, I'll never unlock all of the achievements. I'll never access that golden elevator. And I'll never collect all the pieces of the Luchador mask. But I had fun beating one boney ass after another after another.

23747182.review:
The short of it: Guacamelee delivers a satisfyingly solid metroidvania experience while maintaining an aesthetic and an identity all its own.  

Mechanically, It's a relatively simplistic game that never bothers to introduce much in the way of equipment or character upgrades.  Beyond the obligatory health and energy boosts, there are scant few abilities to be found as you scale impossibly tall trees and chicken your way through ruins saturated with lava, but the game draws out its platforming sections to such a frankly absurd scale that what abilities it does give you never start to feel tired.  In that vein, the level design is demanding, but also quite forgiving.  Falling off platforms never puts you back more than a few seconds, and the intuitive map makes backtracking for hidden items surprisingly painless.  Combat is frantic but solid, the soundtrack full of energy.  The references to nerd culture populate the latin-styled environments like elderly people at a nude beach, but unlike Old Man Wallace, they remain happily in the background, never forcing you to appreciate them, and the game's off-beat humor holds up all the way through the end credits.

Buy it full price or on sale, whatever fits your budget.  You'll be glad you did.

23663908.review:
This is exactly the kind of gem that flourishes from indie companies. Never before have I played a game that fuses platforming, metroidvania, and combat together so well. There's secret passages and hidden collectibles to encourage you to explore and revisit areas, and even a whole secret ending if you explore enough. The combat is quick and simple, but has a lot of depth and flexibility, which is basically perfect for a fighting game. Hard mode is a legitimate combat challenge at times, too, which makes it feel like you really had to fight through the game.

What sets this game apart from other metroidvania games is...its humor. I've really not found a game that actually made me laugh more than this. The writers really knew what they were doing with the characters, and all the jokes are sort of off-hand remarks that you don't expect. Plus there's tons of video game and pop culture references, but almost entirely in the background on signs. Seeing strong bad as an actual mexican wrestler is nice to see, and you have to laugh/cringe at the Rage Comic Era Memes™ set up to fight each other in a wrestling match. 

And it has co-op, too! 

This entire game is a real breath of fresh air from standard stuff, and I wish there was more of it.

22650374.review:
Guacamelee! is advertised as a member of the "Metroidvania" genre, which is largely what drove me to it. It draws on some of the key features of its heritage (accumulation of abilities which open paths and expose secrets) while departing from others (extended exploration, moody atmosphere, isolation). The story, while basic, is overbearing (compared to ancestors of the genre); there are a lot of monologues and cutscenes that probably aren't necessary––they're largely used for jokes. Icons like Super Metroid or Castlevania: Symphony of the Night give broad goals (reach Evil Guy X at the end) and let you work out everything inbetween. Guacamelee! repeatedly says "go here on the map" with small rewards for deviating. But this is a hallmark of modern games, largely.

Like other reviewers have said, this is more of a brawler-platformer. It will appeal to fans of that type of game. The platforming becomes grueling at times, especially if you're using a keyboard. Don't believe other reviews that say it's unplayable with a keyboard; you'll just have to take a break every 45 minutes when your tendons start to hurt.

This is a weak Metroidvania title but a decent brawler-platformer. If you, like me, are/were expecting the former, you're liable to be disappointed.

22255990.review:
Welcome to Guacamelee! The game that puts you under the skin of Juan the Luchador!

Although the game is labelled as a Metroidvania, while on paper that is true, this game is more like a Beat em up platformer, as exploration and discovery is very easy to accomplish due to the map elements layout.

While exploration is really easy, combat and arenas can be a real challenge, and it might be a good idea to play with a gamepad (something the game recommends btw).

Art is beautiful (especially the ending scenes), and animations are cool. The Mexican language and theme is always present and sometimes you feel the need to have some tortillas and enchiladas. The game also makes references about other several other games, including Metroid, Spelunky and even Zelda, which brings some humor into the mix.

In essence a good action game. You can't go wrong with this one.

22110436.review:
The graphics and designs are really good and fun, and the platforming and combats are very well designed and it evolves giving more and more difficulty, some times to a ridiculous level, seriously, there are times when devs seem to have forgotten what's fun and what's utter frustrating >:( 
The levels are very fun to investigate and come back to grab the secrets you couldn't before gaining the new abilities, and you'll be able to buy and improve your character's skills and get new costumes that will give you new strenghts at the cost of new weaknesses
The game got me really frustrated at the point of quitting the game some time ago, and now that I've come back to the game and advanced quite a lot, I've reached other peaks of overwhelming difficulty. Even though, I can't say it's a bad game, I'm sure it depends on each person's skills, but the thing here is that there's no way around it. There's no difficulty switch for the platforms going up, so if you're not able to do quick and complex combinations of buttons in the perfect exact order and timing, you'll just get stuck there not able to advance the game. That's super annoying and it get's really frustrating.
Lots of hidden items, funny signs and background all over. Really enjoyable game.
The music is simple but it goes well with the theme of the game.
Maybe the suits you can buy could be more helpful, to be honest, only two are, all the rest give you a great advantage but then cripples you with a huge weakness so you never use them, it's kind of a waste...
Anyway, great Metroidvania game!! Recommended but be aware of the high difficulty (mostly on the platform sections)

21920545.review:
Guacamelee has an interesting aesthetic which at points make the game harder, which was probably intended.
It has actually got deeper mechanics than at first glance, due to nice and fairly intutitive ways of combining attacks and tools at your disposal; creating a nice bit of variance in how to dispose of enemies.
Back to the aesthetic choioce: it provides you with a distinct feel which, combined with the music, creates a wacky Mexican atmosphere which I personally appreciated much more than I thought I would. However the music started to annoy me/get samey after a while though, at which point I started listening to my own music, slightly disturbing the atmosphere; however I was way into the gameplay at that point so it didn't matter.
Something else, that can be both good and bad depending on what type of game you like, is the difficulty level which to me seems to bounce up and down a bit, some enemies drive you to levels of madness while others feel pathetic. This may however be due to my way of playing the game.
Finally: I bought this game in a Humble-bundle and just let it sit in my lib for about 12 months, but now I've played it a bit more and I will keep on playing it. I must stress that I like this game alot, recommended for the reasons above (except keeping it unplayed in your lib for a long time).
Fiercely recommended!

The first time I tried playing through this game, I gave up for almost 2 years. I wasn't quite sure why. 

I recently retried, because this is a good game and I didn't understand why I disliked it. I did figure out why, though, as I got to a certain mechanic that turned every platforming incident into a timing and reaction dependent stress-fest with massive consequences for failure. 

Didn't help that the fighting gets progressively sloppier as you get more combos. I happen to not like combos. Also for some reason, the grappling speeds up as you progress. This makes it harder to do the grappling combos, even though they're simple as hell.

Ultimately, I didn't like the combo based fighting and the platforming turned into an unduly frustrating experience. I think it's actually a good game, still, but I don't like it and I won't recommend it as such. If you like combos and super meat boy platforming, go for it.

21432152.review:
It's a simple story, man loves woman, she gets kidnapped, you save her by fighting evil. Simple controls, intuitive, and very responsive. There's no confusion, everything is clear cut and you barely give off any sweat. That is for the first part of the game.

This game ramps up in difficulty as you soon get familiar with the movement, combos and controls. Does it stop ramping up in difficulty? Yes, after you beat the game. There's something in there from a range of genres. It's at time a complex puzzle game using game mechanics that you thought you were familiar with. Sometimes it's a gauntlet of enemies that you punish yourself for careless moves. Other times it's a Super Meatboy precision-esque platformer that can frustrate you, yet give you that burst of euphoria when you pass a certain stage.

It's a 2-4 hour game to just finish the story. Extra 1-5 hours of the optional bonus stages and maps.

The multiplayer portion is greatly to be desired for. It makes the game more fun. It works smoothly and allows for a shared adventure that is no different from playing by yourself, except of course, you have someone to share the memory with.

There's very little one could ask for to make this game any better.

21067770.review:
BEWARE: Guacamelee should be labeled as "REQUIRES CONTROLLER" on Steam. Do not buy this game if you intend to play using mouse and keyboard unless you were born with extra fingers or like to include your toes in your gameplay.

During the area Tule Tree, right after you get the double jump move, the game becomes physically impossible to play with a mouse and keyboard.

The game does not recognize multi button mice, so I resorted to the following mapping:

LMB - attack
RMB - special

WASD - directions
Shift - grab
Alt - roll
Space - jump
Q - "change worlds"
E - "chicken mode"

Here is an example of a jumping puzzle which is plain impossible with keyboard and mouse - you have to roll through a hedge, hold the roll to avoid damage, as you are falling down a precipice double jump, then execute an uppercut and grab the wall. This translates to:

direction + roll + hold roll
jump
direction + jump
up + RMB + hold grab

all within less than 1 second. Anothe example - you are between two walls, one has spikes, the other doesn't and the distance between the walls is wide. You have to bounce between walls and "change worlds" while in the air to move the spikes from one wall to the other. This translates to (assuming starting on a left wall):

hold grab
jump + right + jump + change world + grab

If the distance between the two walls is too wide, you may have to thrown in an uppercut which transpates to:

hold grab
jump + right + jump + change world + up + RMB + grab

all in half a second.

Nope, thank you very much.

21004070.review:
Mi primer brawler 2D. Lo que más me ha gustado de Guacamelee es como, poco a poco, va construyendo un sistema de combos con diferentes tipos de golpes que se desbloquean conforme se progresa la historia. Los controles con el mando de Xbox son precisos e intuitivos (con el teclado es prácticamente injugable). Esto es muy importante tanto para la parte de plataformas (algunas de las cuales pueden ser muy complicadas) y la parte de las peleas (que necesitan buen control y mantener un buen combo para no dejarse golpear por los enemigos).

Lo que más destaca del juego es la ambientación, siendo esta de luchadores mexicanos hablando spanglish, con un música mariachi y calaveras de "El día de los muertos" para acompañar. El sentido del humor es también muy bueno y acompaña toda la historia.

La única pega que tengo es el brusco salto de dificultad del nivel final, no he podido finalizar el juego por la pura frustración de intentar ganar las primeras peleas del nivel. Sin embargo, quizá sea más fácil para la gente con más experiencia en el género.

En general un juego muy divertido que divierte durante al menos durante las primeras 10h.
