20556302.review:
Before buying this one check out my review and then go on over to the Guacamelee Super Turbo Championship Edition page and buy that version.

I must say Guacamelee is one of those gems you come across that screams to have a good review written for it. 

This game has all the key elements necessary to make it a fun game and keep it interesting enough to keep you playing start to finish. Granted its replay factor is kind of small, but you'll get more than your moneys worth out of the first play through. Enough to justify buying this special old stile side scroller.

The graphics are great, and they never waver from the over all feel of the story.

The sound is fun and engaging, and though I'm not much into Mexican music the music they used in this game is upbeat and high quality.

The story presents itself well, and is pretty straightforward. It’s not convoluted or over blown. There’s only one major twist, but I won't tell anyone what it is. You’ll have to play it in its entirety to find out.

The puzzles are well rounded, and get progressively harder the farther into the game you get, and it can get frustrating, but that's all part of the games charm, just play through them one at a time, and enjoy the experience.

The power progression is easily spaced as far as getting abilities and using them to complete tasks.

There’s not much in the way of back tracking, but some is necessary to get everything in the game, and to accomplish all the achievements.

There are only two things I can think of, as been a slight disadvantage in the game.

First, it requires a controller (trust me on this it's almost impossible without one).

Second, there is a lot of jumping puzzles. If you want to complete everything you'll have to do them, but that's a minimal issue if you have a controller.

All in all this game is a spot on homage to old stile side scrolling adventure games. I can't stress enough that you should pick it up because you won't be disappointed.

This game has no right to be as good as it is. The premise is ridiculous; a cartoony Super Metroid type game based around a Luchidor wrestler. But, oh man is it good. It pushes all the right buttons for me.

LIke
+ Slick art style
+ Smooth controls
+ Nice gated progression with cool movement abilities
+ Humour and easter eggs
+ Characters and story are very likeable

Dislike
- Not much to dislike
- The theme may be putting some people off from a very good game, but that's THEIR problem.

It's been a while since I played and I don't remember much that I didn't like about it, so I'd call that a win for the developers. If they made another one, I would buy it.

The theme isn't my thing, but it was well done enough that I can look past it in the name of an excellent example of a metroidvania.

20223163.review:
Totalmente recomendado, visualmente es una joya, las animaciones, las paletas de colores, los diseños de personajes y escenarios están integrados en un todo que te absorbe rápidamente, sumando una buena banda sonora y un sentido del humor muy efectivo, el juego esta garantizado para desafiarte y hacerte reír una y otra vez.
-PROS
   +Excelentes gráficos, animación y banda sonora.
   +Hermoso diseño de niveles y desafiantes plataformas.
   +Modo de combate amplio y fresco con gran número de habilidades a descubrir y utilizar.
   +Gran jugabilidad con insuperable programación para jugar tanto con controlador como con teclado.
   +Modo Multijugador
   +Gran valor de re-jugabilidad.
   +Divertido sentido del humor, lleno de referencias y tributos a los grandes videojuegos de las primeras generaciones.
-CONTRAS
   -No tiene penalidades ni sistema de derrota.

El combate es muy satisfactorio, las combinaciones en los combos se van diversificando conforme se aprenden nuevos movimientos por lo que los combates se mantienen frescos y renovándose a lo largo del juego, y aunque los enemigos se repiten una y otra vez es difícil rechazar una pelea.
Los niveles están llenos de secretos y caminos a los que no se puede acceder en un solo recorrido, con nuevas habilidades, el valor de rejugabilidad de cada nivel es alto para los jugadores que disfrutan pasar un juego al 100%, existen además un par de misiones secundarias que no interrumpen el diseño lineal de la historia.
Los retos en la plataformas son muy divertidos y pueden llegar a ser muy desafiantes, aunque el juego es muy benevolente al momento de 'fallar' un escenario o perder una pelea, los checkpoints están ampliamente distribuidos en los escenarios y si fallas alguna de las plataformas el juego rápidamente te reposiciona para otra oportunidad sin ninguna clase de castigo, por lo que el juego en general no ofrece un verdadero desafío mas allá de los ofrecidos en los retos de las plataformas.

I'm not someone who is intimitely familiar with platformers nor am I someone accustomed to the blissful feeling of completeing games. These were the two reasons why I felt like I had to play this after being seduced by the vivid colors and humerous writing, and I'm so glad I played Guacamelee. 

Guacamelee brings me back to playing the old Metroid games on my Gameboy Advance, and the game knows it. Entire game mechanics are in-jokes which are a small part of the fantastic sense of humor of this title. The game takes place in technically an open world, where you can go to any area at any time, assuming you've unlocked the required move to reach the location. Despite being open, you will ALWAYS know exactly where to go, and the areas area small enough as to not feeling like any time is wasted traveling. 

Unlike Metroid, Guacamelee features a fantastic brawling combat system which was deftly designed to grow in complexity at the perfect rate I was learning the game. Without being hindered by petty realism, you get to beat to staisfyingly beat up skeletons and throw them at their friends. Boss fights are almost always challenging but so incredibly satisfying when victorious. 

The game is wrapped in a nice simple ~6 hour story where I always knew what my purpose was and what the stakes are. It's nothing very emotional but it succeded in giving the gameplay meaning. 

All in all, Guacamelee was an incredibly satisfying game to complete and I'd recomend it to anyone interested in the genre of 2D platforming adventures.

19919996.review:
Un excelente juego que brilla en todos los aspectos que se presentan: plataformas, lucha y ambiente mejicano. Y es que el juego es solo eso, pero lo hace tan bien, que es todo lo que vas a necesitar.

Empecemos por la parte de plataformas, al principio te presentan un simple salto y movimientos direccionales y eso es todo, pero mediante mas avanzas vas desbloquendo distintos poderes que te permiten saltar por las paredes, doble salto y hasta triple salto, además de poder acelerar mediante diferentes movimientos mientras estas en el aire. Todo esto da un sentimiento de curiosidad al principio para descubrir todos los movimientos y otro sentimiento de satisfacción alrededor de la mitad del juego cuando ya has dominado la mayoria de los movimientos y puedes moverte con total control por el aire. Simplemente genial

Lo siguiente es la lucha, esta perte y las plataformas son los principales recursos del juego, cuando luchas, los movimientos son exactamente los mismos a cuando saltas y recorres el mundo (ej el movimiento "gancho" sirve para saltar en la mitad del aire pero tambien para mandar a un enemigo por los aires) y ademas puedes mezclarlos para unir TODOS los movimientos del juego en un combo enorme, y encima repetirlos en sucesion (para dar una idea mi combo record fue de 372 golpes) con esto ya te puedes imaginar que el juego da una gran variedad y libertad de movimientos que mejor se adapten a ti, puediendo tener dos jugadores totalmente distinos combos y estilos de pelea.

y por ultimo el ambiente mejicano, esto es mas secuandario pero ayuda mucho a que no se haga repetitivo, digo ambiente mejicano y no historia porque realmente la historia no es la gran cosa: raptan a la hija del presidente y tienes que ir a rescatarla (nuca hecho antes en ningun videojuego, nunca) pero el juego no se concentra en la historia y se centra mas en la ambientacion. Los paisajes, los colores fuertes, la musica (por cierto absolutamente EXCELENTE musica) y los personajes, además de algunas mecánicas como cambiar entre el mundo de los vivos y el mundo de los muertos, todo esto genera el ambiente de que realmente estas en un pueblucho mejicano.

Talvez la única desventaja es que aunque la ambientación cubre la parte de la historia, me hubiera gustado una historia mas profunda.

Normalmente haría una lista pero son muy pocos aspectos. 10/10. Uno de los mejores plataformeros de estos ultimos años

19910232.review: I grew up with platformers. It's one of my favourite game genres, and I must say that this is one of the best I've played. Guacamelee has some of the best combat in a platformer ever, requiring trigger- finger timing, focus, and an awareness of various interesting mechanics. On top of this, it has A- class platforming. Some of the puzzles and labyrinths in this game had me equally infuriated and addicted. Also, the story is awesome, with a few really cool characters and plenty of humour thrown in. Packaging it all is a really striking and comic art style which just elevates the entire experience. For these reasons, Guacamelee is one of my favourite platformers of all time. Highly recommended!

19901201.review:
[Played Solo Only]
I really want to like this game. It tries to be so many things: a brawler with controls like Smash Bros., a metroid-vania, an intense platformer and a collage of gaming memes. In Guacamelee's attempt be all these great things it loses its balance.

For example, I went back and forth between really enjoying myself to frustration a lot. I would be jamming out to the music, thinking that I was decent at the game and then I spend the next 15 minutes on the same bogus platforming or fighting segments. It felt like I was being cheated, after all, wasn't I good at the game just a minute ago? There are just some places where the game gets brutal and it can really catch you off guard.

Most of the bosses are just repetitive and way to random, making them less of a test then a large thorn in your side. Hence the name Guaca-Melee, this game turns out to emphasize fighting a lot and has a ton of combos. Thing is, they don't work on bosses so what's the point? In a boss battle you can get maybe 5 hits on them until they teleport away, swap dimensions or throw up another shield. Similarly, combos on regular enemies get punished as you can just get more than a few hits in before someone else takes a swing at you. In fact, avoiding longer combos and just going for random stray hits after dodging an onslaught of attacks for long time is the best way to avoid damage in the later stages of the game.

Before the real challenging bits kicked in, I was ready to buckle down and 100% this game. In order to do this I would've had to deal with Guacamelee turning into Super Meat Boy (Kid you not, saw blades and everything). Some of the collectables have insane challenges behind then while other are way too simple to obtain. It's this general sense of "Oh, you can enjoy yourself...after banging your head into the wall”, which disagrees with me. Challenge is great. Throwing yourself at a wall until you win isn’t a good challenge and certainly isn't rewarding, for me at least.

Go ahead and buy it. It can get pretty cheap. I loved the earlier stages and I might be a lot of fun with a companion, who knows? Everything is stylized and unique from the music to the characters and to the art. I’m just a tad salty that I didn’t end up loving this game. I may not like it but I would recommend it.

19790994.review:
Finished 100% in about 14 hours. This is the most fun I've had playing a game in years. Metroid is my favorite franchise, and this takes everything I love about Metroid and adds only good things on top of it.

Exploration:
The first thing everyone thinks of when thinking Metroidvania. This game does a great job of giving places to find and come back to when you've gotten new abilities. But it does what the best of Metroid did by not just giving you a key to open the path, but a challenge to be overcome by utilizing the abilities you've earned. If you want to see what I'm talking about go to youtube for "Guacamelee Tree Tops."

Combat:
What really surprised me is how deep the combat system is. With only a handful of enemy types the game presents new and dynamic challenges by combining and recombining the enemy types, giving some of them shields which need to be taken down with specific moves, and putting some in a different plane where they can damage you but you can't damage them until you shift to their plane. The challenges in El Infierno really highlight just how deep the combat system is and are a fantastic challenge. A special mention must go out to the fantasic boss fights. They were challenging and engaging, and really tested your ability to quickly respond to varied attacks.

Story:
The story is pretty sparse, but what it does have I found very enjoyable and humorous. It's nothing that's going to change your world, but it's a cherry on top of a great experience that compliments it well.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. If you like metroidvania games this is a must have.

19455349.review:
El juego Guacamelee es en verdad un muy interesante, magnifico y sobresaliente juego plataformero y de luchas.
Controlamos a Juan Aguacate, un hombre cualquiera que se convierte en luchador tras conseguir una mascara mandada por los dioses.
Tiene una ambientación mexicana muy interesante, a mi parecer se siente genial poder experimentar un juego tan divertido y perfecto con toda la interfaz en español (incluyendo posters, letreros, carteles e imágenes en este idioma), es interesante, se puede sentir el amor y el esfuerzo metido por todo el equipo tras cada segundo de juego.
El juego tiene un control sencillo, con combos legendarios y geniales. Puedes derrotar a tus adversarios con unos cuantos golpes o dejarlos en ridículo con una mezcla de botones de experto profesional hacker "fack de laif" como si fuera lo mas normal del mundo.
Responden de una forma fluida, sin errores o ralentizaciones, ya desde el momento en que te mueves sientes que los comandos están tan pulidos que hasta te limpian la suciedad residual de otros títulos que no valieron la pena.
La música es ideal para el titulo, no sobre sale mucho, y eso es perfecto por que no se siente música mala, sino una música mexicana ambientada perfectamente para el juego.
Las referencias las encontraras regadas en todo el juego, son fantásticas, es divertido poder encontrarlas en cada parte del juego, son mil veces mejores que cualquier imagen graciosa que encontrarías publicada del perfil de alguna empresa mexicana en facebook.
No es un juego para todo publico, debería ser probado por las personas que adoran los juegos de plataformas o donde se puedan hacer un sin numero de combos. Lo recomiendo amplia mente, vale la pena comprarlo a precio completo por tanto esfuerzo que se ve reflejado en el titulo.

19371422.review:
Es obvia la razón por la que este juego se destaca tanto, a pesar de ser una rendición a los grandes clásicos plataformeros - y sus obvias referencias-, es uno de los beat em ups que puedo recomendar por diferentes puntos:

- Gameplay: No hay nada mejor que ser un luchador y demostrarlo dando unas buenas madrizas con un sistema de combos bastante agradable que te permitirá derrotar a tus enemigos de la manera más estilosa posible, poderes muy originales (Sobre todo con los nombres ;D) y la forma en que requerirás usarlos en diferentes ocasiones, no en un solo momento en específico como muchos otros plataformeros. 

-Historia y arte: Quizás sea un típico "salva a la princesa del castillo del villano", pero lo que le dá un toque especial es el hecho de que todo está ambientado con el hermoso estilo mexicano del Día de los muertos, no solamente te adentras a calabozos, si no que en ciertos momentos pareciera que estás dando un tour a las características arquitectónicas de famosas culturas prehispánicas de México, al igual que con pequeños tintes cómicos y enemigos bastante geniales en mi opinión.

-Música: Debo admitir que algo que me fascina es la combinación de instrumentos acústicos y algo moderno, en este caso, Guacamelee lo hace bastante bien, lo único malo que podría decir de este juego es que la melodía contra los jefes pudo haber sido un poco más intensa, es todo, pero en cuanto a niveles, calabozos y demás tiene un soundtrack bastante original.

- Replay value: Bueno hay muchos secretos y logros, al igual que trajes y habilidades para desbloquear, lo que hace que este juego aún después de haberlo acabado te haga continuar en una busqueda para conseguir un 100%.

Conclusión: Un juego que aborda bastante bien los colores y motivos de las tradiciones mexicanas al igual que darte la oportunidad de dar palizas al más puro estilo de la lucha libre, muy recomendable.

TL;DR Das p*tazos a montones + musica chingona + historia agradable +calacas + colores en todos pinches lados + POLLO POWER = Juego chingón.

19086700.review:
[quote=Wasterbull] Reseña en español[/quote]

[i]Un juego del género MetroidVania que se hace respetar.[/i]

[h1] SINOPSIS[/h1]
[h1][code][i]En Pueblucho vivía Juan, un amante de lucha libre y tiene cierta relación anterior con la Hija del presidente, un día Calaca  junto a sus cómplices invade y rapta a la Hija del presidente, Juan en su intento de salvarla, muere a manos del antagonista, al final es elegido para llevar la Máscara del Luchador, con el fin de evitar de que Calaca fusione el Mundo de los Vivos con los Muertos.[/i][/code][/h1]

[h1] GAMEPLAY[/h1]
Es un juego que captura perfectamente la esencia verdadera de un género que no siempre es bien usado o aprovechado el 100% del potencial; MetroidVania. Es sublime la jugabilidad, es recomendable jugarlo con control que teclado, cada quien con su gusto. Cuenta con modo cooperativo, es la primera vez que lo veo en un género MetroidVania, le va perfecto. Combina con muchos géneros como lucha, hack and slash y demás.

[h1] GRÁFICA[/h1]
La historia visual es bastante atrapante como jugabilidad, cuenta con muchas parodias y referencias a la cultura popular, me han hecho reír y ponerme una sonrisa con sólo ver unos carteles y muchas referencias gamers incluso cómics. El trabajo artístico es impecable, al principio no me causaba un interés y al jugarlo, me equivoqué y eso Calaca no me perdonará. ¡Salve Juan!

[h1] MÚSICA[/h1]
Perfecto, me gustó mucho.

[h1] OPINIÓN SOBRE EL VIDEOJUEGO	[/h1]
Sólo pura alabanzas tengo sobre el juego, podría decir muchas cosas pero no puedo ya que haría spoiler, recomiendo que compren en oferta el Guacamelee! Complete para disfrutarlo.

[h1] PUNTUACION FINAL 9/10	[/h1]


[h1] PRO +[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Juegazo con una historia atractiva y graciosa, los personajes y escenarios.
    [*]OST y Guacamelee! Super Turbo Championship Edition, la versión más completa.
    [*]Cromos y Logros
[/list]

[h1]CONTRA -[/h1]

18895273.review:
[h1]Intro:[/h1]
[u][b]TLDR:[/b][/u] Gameplay: Outstanding!  -  Visuals: Stunningly beautiful artstyle -  Story: Fitting  -  Coop: Double the fun, though making the game easier at some points.  -  9/10

Amazing 2D sidescroller with a very broad combat system! Boss-battles, mini-bosses, loads of different enemies, platforming, jump-puzzles with various difficulties, and a great storyline. A Masterpeice! If you like a challanging platformer/combat-sidescroller; this is it for you. 

Originally got this game through a HumbleBundle and wasen't expecting much from it. Boy was I in for a surprise!

[h1]Pros and Cons:[/h1]
[b]++ Pros:[/b]
+ Local coop
+ Responsive controls
+ Full controller support
+ Combat with a lot of variations
+ Customizations
+ Fun and fine story
+ Side-material (and loads of it)
+ Immersive world
+ Artstyle

[b]- - Cons:[/b]
- Fairly short actual story
- Coop restricted to local

[h1]Details:[/h1]
The games features a coop mode, but this is however only on a local pc. The coop mode is essentialy adding another character to the game with next to none extra interactions. This is however a neat feature for the game, and is very fun. doubles the people, double the fun, right!? right indeed.

The combat and movement system is extremely good, you control every action, and your charactor is a super responsive slave to your controller of choice. It features full controller support, which I personally find great for this kind of game. Great use of combo variation and at some points it is even a necesity to win a duel or complete a challange.

Wether you jump your way thorugh spikes, traps and platforms, or (Guaca)melee your way through hazzards of enemies, It's allways a very good mixtures of the two main gameplay mechanics. The game has a lot of mechnics, which are all very well explained, and it forces you to utilizes almost everyone of them. You can't just stomp thorugh the game using one move, or one combat technique. Variation is key to defeat certain enemies.

One word *Sidematerial*!!! Side-quests (so to speak), challange modes, collectiables, unlockables. Guacamelee has pretty much all of it. It also featues a some custimization to suit your playstyle as well. Some of the challanges may be difficult and frustratin! I must admit I at one point spent 1½ hours completing a single jump-puzzle... I suck... damn my stubborness. And yet other parts may be a peice of cake.

The overall game is an eye-pleaser. The artline is amazing, especially considering it being a "just" a 2D sidescroller. You can really feel the mood of the game, being pumped up with references to other games, memes and various sidestories. It's all in the detail of the tiny thing. And there is a lot of tiny things in this game. Makes for an overall better experience. It is very rewarding to go around exploring the world of guacamelee, trust me on this one!

The story is pretty straight-forward, humorous, filled with some unique characters. This is however not the bearing factor, as it falls a bit short compared to the standard of the other parts of the game. Only problem is that you can rush through the main storyline in a matter of a few hours, which leaves you storywise a bit dissatisfied. The loads of extra content largely outweights this problem though.

[h1]Final verdict:[/h1]
One of the best sidescrolles i've ever played. Rewarding to play.
"Me Gusta". I rate this game 9/10.

Guacamelee is an action-platformer with an emphasis on "backtracking", developed by Ontario based "Drinkbox Studios". 

Stylisticly, Guacamelee's luchadorean theme, "Dia de los Muertos" aesthetic, and Mariachi inspired soundtrack all blend together seemlessly. The combo focused combat is satisfying, and the controls are responsive enough to allow for extremely precise movements.

If I were to point out any negatives, it would be the game's hamfisted lack of subtlety with respect to its "Metroid inspired exploration" and massive number of popular culture references.

18498797.review:
A very good Metroidvania Brawler Platform Game that's also pretty challenging.

PROS
-Open World to Explore
-2 Playable Characters
-Local Co-Op
-Challenging Platform Puzzles
-Fun Brawling Combat
-Great Soundtrack

CONS
-Backtracking
-Some High Difficulty Segments 
-No Online Co-Op

GAMEPLAY

The game plays like a usual platform game with brawling style combat that works very well.  You unlock special moves like you would any other Metroidvania style game & you will use those new moves to solve more puzzles & reach areas that you couldn't previously.  If you ever wondered what a Metroid game would play like with melee combat well then this is the game for you!

OVERALL

The game is fairly short but all of it is enjoyable.  The fights are fun & can get pretty tough later on.  Same for the platform segments.  The only complaint I have is in order to get the best ending you gotta do these insanely hard challenges that take a while.  I managed to do them all & the satisfaction from beating them was pretty sweet.  The ending is worth it.

Also, if you don't own or ever played this game you're better off getting the new Turbo Championship Edition.  It is essentially the same game with extra features & more content.

18183854.review:
Guacamelee is an action platformer that was released in August 2013, published and developed by DrinkBox Sudios. Originally pinned as a Sony exclusive on the PS3 and Vita, it was however later ported to PC before eventually getting the "Gold Edition" releasing on all of the platform in mid 2014. Guacamelee is heavily based on Mexican culture and lore. 

You play the role of Juan, a powerful luchador fighter. You will be fighting various different enemies in this platforming metroidvania style game. You start off with a very basic arsenal of attacks which you can pull off such as a basic three attack combo, but eventually you can work you way up to combos which can consist of eight plus button presses! (I never managed to pull off one of these more than once). Juan will also learn a various number of "out of combat" skills, such as wall jumping and the ability to turn into a chicken. The platforming element of Guacamelee was probably the most annoying for me, mainly because I am just terrible at the genre, but I found the jumping puzzles to be just tedious and grew very thin on my patience at times.  The fighting side of the game is done very well; the combo system and special moves you can pull off are all really well done - some fights you will end up getting swamped by enemies, but it won't matter since you can throw together a number of punches which will just knock them out with ease. 

Graphically, there isn't too much to shout about, it's a 2d side scroller so generally nothing spectacular is going to be seen, however the art style on show is gorgeous. This really portrays the Mexican style of game extremely well, and is probably the game's best feature. It looks very similar to the recent release of "The Book of Life" from 2014. Whilst it has a cartoon look to it, there is still an element of maturity and darkness in some of the scenes. 

The plot in Guacamelee! was nice. It is your typical adventure style story, the humble farmer who is in love with the El Presidente's daughter, the daughter then gets kidnapped, and it is your task to rescue her so you can live happily ever after.  The plot is very well thought out, offers a couple of cliffhangers and interesting twists and turn a long the way. Guacamelee also has a couple of comical moments in too to lighten the mood. 

Guacamelee is another game which doesn't have voice acting in; I would really of liked to have seen (or heard) it included, because there is quite a bit of text to read through and I would of thought that having voice acting would make people get more immersed into this wonderful world on show. Having said that, the sound track is amazing. It is playing pretty much constantly throughout the game, and it never wears thin. 

As I said above, the I found the platforming side of the game to be the most annoying, mainly because it is super difficult to progress in the game due to a number of jumping puzzles which had me close to rage quiting a number of times. Eventually you will get past them, it just takes perseverance and a lot of patience (something I am slowly finding out that I don't have very much of).  Most of the fight scenes are easily mastered and you probably won't find your self dying an awful lot in this game. The opportunity to raise the difficulty level may change this though, which is something more confident veteran combo fighters will want to check out. 

The world in which Guacamelee is set in, is very well fleshed out. There are plenty of NPCs to interact with, loads of side quests to find and complete, most of which are of no relevance to the main story, and is just an extra way to generate funds. Touching again on the topic of special abilities, you will also find your self backtracking to a degree in the game so you can use the new abilities you have just unlocked to reach places which you couldn't before, to unlock chests, health bonuses etc. You will also find a number of shops scattered around the world where you can purchase health and stamina upgrades along with a number of other power ups. 

A full playthrough of Guacamelee took me almost eleven hours to complete; this was with the inclusion of the majority of the side quests too. I would say that eleven hours is just the right amount for me. The game also has a local co-op mode which you will find adds a whole new element to the game as well and is certainly worth a second playthrough on this mode, easily touching this game up to the twenty hour mark - and then of course there are the higher difficulty modes you can play on should you desire so. There is plenty of content on offer in Guacamelee to sink your teeth into.

No technical issues here; played on 4k resolution, at a steady 60 FPS as should be expected from a 2d side scroller. You will need a controller to play this game to any degree of competency though, simple because the jumping puzzles and combos would just be ridiculously hard to counter on a keyboard. The options menu also includes a wide variety of options when it comes to selecting resolutions and frame rates too, which is always nice to see. 

In conclusion, Guacamelee! is a really rounded out game, which is certainly one of the best indie titles to come out in recent years. The addition of local co-op makes this game even better, and fans of metroidvania style games really need to check this out. The price of £9,99 is an absolute bargain for the amount of content on show here too. 

[b][u] Tom's Score Card[/u][/b]
1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
[b][u]4) Highly recommended[/u][/b]
5) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Very well designed platformer. (Should I call it a metroidvania?)
Controls are pretty tight, although there are some frustrating moments when you locked in landing lag after an aerial attack and can't avoid getting comboed. That just means plan better. As Smash Bros legend Isai always said "Just don't get hit."

New attacks are gained as you progress through the game, including new movement options that create some pretty cool platforming challenges, usually involving wall jumps. None have been terribly challenging, but maybe that's just because I'm used to games like They Bleed Pixels, Super Meat Boy, and Electronic Super Joy which all are much more difficult platforming challenges.

But that doesn't take anything away from this game's appeal to me. It's hilarious. The story is fun. There are mini side-quest challenges, There are upgrades you can purchase. The combat is just the right level of difficult to keep you wanting to try again when you fail, because you feel like it's your own fault every time you die. That's important. It feels fair.

I love it. You'll enjoy it. Check it out.

17478712.review:
In the realm of indie games, there are a lot to choose from. How will you know the right game when you see it? Guacamelee! is a game that catches your attention immediatly because of the name itself. It's an awesome name that gives you a pretty good idea of what the game is about: you beat up people/things in some kind of Mexican setting. And if the name alone is awesome and raises your expectations high, you're still going to be blown away by the actual game. One can use many words to describe this game, such as fun, challenging and nostalgic. The word that comes to my mind when I think about this game, is perfect. Guacamelee! is borderline godly, and perhaps the best platformer I have ever played. The game is, as described by the store page, a Metroidvania style beat 'em up. And don't be surprised when you find that there are more things in this game related to Metroid and Castlevania than just the gameplay: the game is OVERFLOWING with references to classic games, indie games and even D_A_N_K_M_E_M_E_S for those of you who like to pay reddit or 4chan or Imgur or 9gag or whatever a visit. To be honest, I don't know what websites aren't dealing with some kind of meme infection these days, not that I'm complaining. Anyways, these references are really just a huge load of fan service, and hopefully you will find them just as enjoyable as I did. But the best thing about this game is of course not the references, but the gameplay. The platforming is tighter than jeans in a vacuum, and all the punches and kicks always hit spot-on. You can also perform special attacks that also help you progress in the game, not to mention throw your enemies when they've accumulated a certain level of damage. This is really useful as you can throw the enemies at each other to knock them over, and it's just damn fun to do. The visuals are cartoon-like and really sweet to look at. The music is actually very good and always fits the mood perfectly, and even changes into something darker, more ambient and even dubstep-influenced at times when you switch from the World of the Living to the World of the Dead. You can do that btw. Unfortunately though, it's not very memorable. The story, I guess I should have brought it up earlier: you are a man by the name of Juan, who becomes a luchador so that he can save the world from a dead man named Carlos Calaca who have overthrown el diablo himself and now plans to take over both the World of the Living and the World of the Dead by sacrificing el presidente's daughter. Bad stuff, and nobody wants it to happen, so thank goodness for Juan! The characters and dialogue are sometimes funny, other times more forgettable, but very sufficient all in all. This isn't one of those games where the story is the main aspect. The ending, which I'm not going to spoil, was, however, surprisingly sad and emotional. All in all, Guacamelee! is a great experience that everybody that likes Metroidvania-style games and platformers in general owe themselves to play. One might say that the game is a little short, but if you try to find secrets and collect all the treasure, like I kind of attempted, you will definitely get your money's worth. You will also find a lot of challenge if you decide to hunt some orbs or complete the challenges in El Infierno, which, of course, is included in this edition ;) I've also heard that playing co-op is fun, not that I ever got to try it... Bottomline, this game is a masterpiece, get a firm grip on el controlador and get ready to Guacamelee!
10/10
Edit: Nominee for the "Divine Mexican Bliss" Award.

It's a fun game, but it gets repetitive and has some crazy difficulty spikes. The game itself plays a bit like a simplified Super Smash Bros., with simple combos that you chain together. You traverse through Mexican-themed environments fighting enemies and gaining powers. Also, while this game advertises itself as a Metroidvania, it is more like a beat-em-up with some exploration. You'll never find yourself lost, and there is (with maybe an exception or two) only one way to reach your goal. There are side quests and small detours, where you collect items or solve puzzles, but they only improve your character's stats and aren't crucial to the main adventure. 
My recommendation is to buy in a sale if the game seems appealing, but it is far from a masterpiece. Be sure to have a controller, too!

17314546.review: Guacamelee is a love letter to the Metroidvania genre, in the form of a super-powered romp through the world of Mexican folklore. You are Juan Aguacate, a destitute agave farmer who finds his village under attack by the undead army of Carlos Calaca. The love of his life, who happens to be the daughter of el presidente, has been kidnapped. What is Juan to do? Why, acquire a magic lucha mask and go on a non-linear platforming adventure, get powerups from "choozo" statues, power-slam bad guys, find secrets and navigate rather tricky jumping puzzles, of course. Guacamelee oozes style from beginning to end, with a colorful palette, excellent music and a well-used light/dark world mechanic, requiring the player to frequently switch Juan between the living world and the Mexican land of the dead via portals, often in  mid-jump.  But the game is inconsistent in difficulty. The combat is generally managable and the boss fights are quite simply awesome, but some of the jumping puzzles are incredibly frustrating. In addition, to reach the game's golden ending, it is neccessary to obtain a number of secret items, some of which are located at the end of some fiendishly difficult challenge rooms, many of which, like the trick jump room with its accursed disappearing platforms, I was unable to complete, and this left a bad taste in my mouth. The final boss is also quite difficult, requiring you to demonstrate a mastery over all the abilities you have learned over the course of the game, but when I had finished, I was very satisfied dispite not getting the best ending. I would recommend the game to any fans of Metroidvania, but with caution- it is not a forgiving experience.

17311969.review: This is an amazing game overall! The music, story, art everything about it is very well done and just really fun fighting game over all. 17304210.review:
This game is a solid action platformer. I love the mexican art style it actually reminds me of samurai jack crossed with mucha lucha. It's bright and colorful, and the writing is pretty funny too. The combat is simple but fun, and throwing enemies always feels satisfying. 
I will say that this is a legitimately hard game, and that is mostly due to the platforming. There is a light world/ dark world mechanic and depending which world you are in some of the platforms will not be solid. What the game does is alternate between light world and dark world platforms, meaning taht you have to jump, then switch worlds in time in order to land on the next platform. If you fail it usually brings you back to the beggining. So the game pushes you out of your comfort zone in order to advance and starts you back at the beginning if you fail. However this game never rushes you and encourages you to take your time to master each area. 
Also this game is by no means short. There are plenty of secrets and the game encourages back tracking as you unlock special abilities that let you access previously innaccessible areas. This game also comes with 2 player drop in/ drop out co-op so you can bring a friend. Just make sure to bring a controller though.
I highly reccommend this game with a 8/10, great game.

17210537.review:
There is plenty of things that I loved about Guacamelee. It has a very simple and to-the-point combo list. It rarely reuses puzzles and situations. Most puzzles and bosses and challenging but not too much. And most importantly, it doesn't take itself too seriously.

But, in a way, it also does take itself seriously. Its challenges are designed to be just manageable, to push you to the limits of your skill. That would have been great if you actually had that level of control. But you don't. The controls are sticky. So, for example, your "D" command becomes "arrow+D", because you were using arrows moments ago, and that changes everything. The developers recommend using a gamepad, but there's no real reason why the keyboard shouldn't work. They simply decided to neglect it.

At the same time, combat is based on dissing and receiving stuns. It is entirely possible that the enemies will chain-stun you until you die, and there's nothing you can do to recover.

I ragequit this game many times. When it works, it's awesome. But very often it doesn't work, and it often feels like losing wasn't your fault. And that is the biggest fault in a game. A player should never feel like he's being punished for things beyond his control.

I know that, technically, it's my fault for not executing the jumps perfectly. However, between the inconsistent difficulty and the imperfect controls, I don't see why I should keep replaying the same section to perfect my jumps to such a degree. The game isn't that addictive or rewarding. What stayed with me from Guacamelee wasn't the good times as much as the ragequits. And for that reason, I don't consider this game a good experience.

The Good

+Fantastic Mexican setting. The main characters, the enemies, the places - all of it adds to the experience
+Combo system is forgiving, which makes combat fun
+Difficulty and its scaling are appropriate. All enemies telegraph their attacks: with that knowledge, spacing and timing you can beat anything

The Bad
-[url=store.steampowered.com/app/275390/]Super Turbo Championship Edition[/url] exists, which should have been DLC and not an entire new game
-El Diablo's Domain could have been tougher and longer
-Some uncommon glitches while fighting, which led to unfair deaths
-The non-videogame-related memes in Santa Luchita are out of place

The bottom line
A carefully crafted platformer with a fun setting and combo system. Even though SuperTurboChampionshipEdition is the game you should be buying, I cannot give a not recommended score solely on that.

You'll easily get comfortable with the vibrant colors, music, and a sense of accomplishment once you start getting ability upgrades.  Then Guacamelee pulls your sombrero down over your face and beats you into the ground with a sack full of empty tequila bottles.

Guacamelee has one level about halfway into the game that is really difficult.  So difficult, I almost gave it a thumbs down, because I would have been really disappointed if I never got past it, since the rest of the game is so good.  I left it alone for several days and then went back to it, finally getting the timing correct to get to the next save point, but my hands looked like gnarled roots when I dropped the controller and begged for mercy.

It's a beat-'em-up 2D side-scrolling platformer with a lot of humor and fun combo moves.  Don't try this one without a comfortable controller.  Also, get it on sale, because if you get stuck in the same place I did and never bother trying to finish, you'll be glad you didn't pay full price.

Guacamelee! is a game that brings nothing new to the front table. Its roots are pretty obvious, as it's a game that pays a staggering homage to the likes of Metroid and Castlevania. However, it adds nice puzzle elements and blends everything with such finesse and precision that elevates this game way beyond the "old school tribute" that many Indy games seem to be around these days, as it's safe to say, the boys from Drinkbox Studios went the extra mile and dwelled way pass their confort zone.

The graphics are amazing, the art has that Comic book feel to it and the colors are warm and well put together. Every character has their own feel and, despite their all sharing that Mexican Luchadore vybe with the masks, skulls and marching mariachis, they have their own sense of indivuality so the game wont bore you with that. Soundtrack is nice as well and the sound effects are really retro, part what I like most about this. 

Apart from the challenging puzzles, the part that I liked most was certainly the bosses, specially the Leopard fight, it was one of the hardest and most fun I've ever faced. 

Overall, great game with a nice amount of replay-value.

16242952.review:
[h1][b]INSPIRADO EN MEXICO, CON AMOR[/b][/h1]

México, como muchos otros países, tiene su folclore inherente que a mas de uno le da curiosidad al respecto; de conocer su historia, sus gustos, la cultura en general y por qué no, la elección a la hora de divertirse observando algo totalmente diferente. En este caso, México un enorme espectáculo que ha sobrepasado las fronteras del mismo país, emigrando hacia otros lugares del mundo: La Lucha Libre Mexicana. Un deporte/espectáculo que despierta pasiones (de las cuales no las entiendo, pero las respeto) y que, mal por bien, ha influido en muchos otros medios mundialmente como el cine, series de TV, incluso videojuegos.

Guacamelee es un claro ejemplo de tomar como escenario el rico folclore mexicano, darle un toque de exploración razonable estilo “metroidvania” y un sistema de combate que te va a entretener un rato largo. Sorprendentemente, este titulo comprende bien cómo debe sentirse acorde al genero dicho anteriormente. Sabe muy bien los aspectos que uno debe considerar para aventurarse a un mundo semi abierto donde podremos encontrar tesoros, habilidades extras, mejores y demás, cosa que no muchos llegan a hacerlo de manera correcta, es más, Guacamelee podria ser uno de los pocos que ha imitado medianamente bien la saga Metroid y post Castlevania: SOTN.

La historia trata de nuestro héroe Juan, un tipo fanático de la lucha libre habitante de Pueblucho, un pueblo (valga la redundancia) muy gentil y en preparativos por la boda de la Hija del presidente, quien al parecer tiene una relación anterior con Juan. En uno de esos andares de la vida, Pueblucho es atacado por el malvado Calaca y sus esbirros con el fin de raptar a la Hija del presidente y comenzar una ceremonia para fusionar el mundo de los vivos con los muertos. Juan en su intento de salvarla, muere a manos del antagonista quien tiempo mas tarde es elegido para llevar la Mascara del Luchador y evitar que la fusión suceda. 

En realidad la narrativa no es muy profunda o emocionante en cuanto a la exposición que refiere mostrar en los primeros minutos, pero es la excusa necesaria para llevarte a una aventura que vas a querer completar al 100%. En si, encontraremos otros personajes divertidos y escenas que te van a hacer sacar una sonrisa ya que, sumado al apartado artístico, la excelente música y la jugabilidad, se suma pequeños guiños a la cultura de internet contemporánea y alguna que otra seudo-broma al genero y sus clichés, por sobre todo de Metroid (quien se deja influenciar bastante).

Definitivamente Guacamelee es más un “Metroid” que un “Castlevania moderno”, puesto que no hay elementos de RPG y las habilidades que hallamos deliberadamente necesarias para progresar a otras áreas o retroceder por pura curiosidad luego de adquirir una técnica que nos permita romper bloques azules del juego, por ejemplo. A lo que va todo esto es que el juego esta diseñado muy bien con respecto a cómo debería sentirse un juego de exploración, con un camino predeterminado que nos lleve del punto A hacia el B, pero que se ramifica hacia otros lugares donde la meta es una habilidad extra (cosa que no hay, lamentablemente), tesoros que contienen dinero para luego invertirlo en trajes, técnicas de lucha libre y aumentar vida o capacidad para ejecutar ataques especiales. En si, no es enorme como Super Metroid, pero hace muy bien en la sensación en general, cosa que, reiterando, pocos llegan a hacerlo.

Otra cosa que se destaca Guacamelee, y puede que sea una de las características que lo definen, es que su dificultad radica en muchas ocasiones en el plataformeo, en zonas donde deberemos usar nuestras habilidades correctamente para superar el obstáculo, aspecto que puede llevarte un tiempo en adaptarte. Aunque si vamos a profundidad jugable, el titulo incorpora otras dos habilidades que las tendremos que dominar: La transformación del Pollo, si bien no tiene un uso en combate será de ayuda para encontrar pasadizos que son inaccesibles siendo Juan, y la segunda es la capacidad para cambiar entre el mundo de los vivos y los muertos. Esta es una peculiaridad que ya se ha visto en Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver (que es el primer ejemplo que se me viene a la cabeza con esta mecánica), que al estar en un reino ciertas plataformas o accesos se materializan que al cambiar, estas desaparecen materializando otras. En si no suceden cambios drásticos en la estructura del juego, pero es algo que tendremos que dominar bastante bien.

El combate es otra cosa interesante que dentro de él, Juan podrá hacer maniobras vistas en la Lucha Libre Mexicana para deshacerse de los múltiples y peligrosos enemigos que se toparan en su camino. Obviamente podremos usar las habilidades extras de combate para hacernos el trabajo un poco más sencillo el asunto y que tiene algo muy propio de los beat 'em up estilo Devil May Cry (Uff..) donde podremos hacer combos en el aire o combinar “con estilo” algunos golpes con otros y hacer tu propia cadena de ataques. Claro que el combate escala a la par con las cucherias que encontramos puesto que mas tarde tendrán escudos en los que necesitaremos usar cierta maniobra para destruirlo o cambiar de mundo para poder atacarlo. Aunque no se lo crea, el combate puede ser muy intenso en algunos momentos donde todo lo dicho anteriormente se mezcla en un solo cuarto, teniendo que debatir quien es nuestra prioridad o cómo intentar disminuir la presión del momento. En si este aspecto no es terriblemente frustrante, pero es parte de la aventura.

En lineas generales, Guacamelee es un excelente juego en todos sus aspectos: gráficos apetecibles y llamativos, gran jugabilidad y mecánicas interesantes de plataformeo, combate trepidante y un apartado sonoro que es de admirar. En cuanto a las versiones que circulan de este titulo, “Guacamelee: Gold Edition” añade algunos DLC como los desafíos del Infierno y trajes extras, en cambio “Guacamelee: Super Turbo Championship Edition” suma lo de la Gold Edition, pero también algunas áreas extras y jefes. Si me preguntan, seria mejor la ultima edición que es la totalidad del paquete, pero si tienes la anterior no es nada de envidiar puesto que es (casi) la misma experiencia agradable de juego.

[b]8/10[/b]

16104216.review:
Guacamelee! Gold Edition which was originally put out on the PS3 Digital store and PlayStation Vita has now been made available on the Steam store with more levels and Steam Workshop functionality. What you get overall though is a great 2D Beat Em Up though with very few flaws.

The story follows Juan, a simple farmer, who while trying to rescue El Presidente’s daughter from Carlos Calaca who is the ruler of the dead world is killed. That’s right , the main character and protagonist is killed in the opening of the game. However Juan is brought back from the dead by the magic of a mask and turned into a all so powerful luchador. Juan then sets out on a adventure to find El Presidente’s daughter. That is a simple form of the story without spoiling some of the excitement. During the story however it displays it’s fantastic sense of humor. Throwing references to everything from Mario to Wreck It Ralph. You get to know a handful of fun character with the most memorable one being the old man who owns the Choozo statues that Juan finds.

 
Guacamelee! Gold Edition

Guacamelee! Gold Edition

 

As you can see the game is beautiful looking. The environments are very brightly colored and lush looking. It boats a very well done art style that looks good in zoomed out scenes as well as close up. The character and enemy types are extremely detailed as well. The music is impressive as well with the mariachi music not only fitting in well but also being quite catchy.

Off to game play we have a very well rounded beat em up / platformer at times. As you progress through the game you will get new masks which will unlock new moves and powers for you. Those moves will help destroy blocks you will come across that can only be destroyed by that move. That color scheme also later applies to enemies with shields. You will also be introduced to a light and dark world with puzzles and platformer sections playing heavily on switching between the two. It can get very difficult however thankfully the game balances it all fairly well. While it is hard the game never manages to get to the point where it is too hard to pass.

Thankfully the controls once learned are pretty tight. The game as well supports control functionality. With good controls the platforming thankfully does well. With leveled up powers you will find yourself doing moves along the lines of a double jump into a wall grab into a uppercut just to reach a platform you need. If you do mess up however and fall to your death the game graciously just warps you back up to the ledge never making you have to redo sections just to fail again.

By defeating enemies and passing areas into the game you gain coins which can be used to level up your character and buy new moves. The stations to upgrade yourself come rather often since they also serve as save points as well.

Boasting very few flaws one of my main gripes with the game is it’s length. The game is rather short lasting only a few hours. Coming in with a $15 price tag the game though is a good deal and provides a lot of fun for it’s cost. I also found at first the combat to be somewhat repetitive though once gaining new powers it freshened up.

Overall Guacamelee! is a great game. Featuring a entertaining story, fantastic graphics, and some great yet hard action and platforming you will have fun through the short journey. It’s well worth checking out.

 

Score :

 

8/10

16016566.review:
Guacamelee! is wrestling, sidescrolling platformer, high-paced, RPG/light, arcade fighting game packaged in a VERY colorful piñata shell. What I think is hilarious is that it's a Canadian dev team that made this game.

Starts off very easy, then gets somewhat difficult *solely* because sometimes it's hard to pull off the timing in the moves. There's a game mechanic in which you have to alternate between two different "dimensions" which is difficult to explain without giving away too much of the story. Speaking of which, is pretty much on par with the Super Mario's story. Serviceable but not a lot of depth. BTW, you can morph into a chicken... Which is actually way more awesome than it sounds.

Game is a little too try-hard in terms of humor, but that's all subjective I suppose.

I can't stress enough, gameplay requires you to have lighting-fast reflexes or you will be forced to play through a lot of areas twice or more until you get it.

The level design is very good. It's challenging but not over the top. The game is pretty short if you're good at it. Which is good because it gets repetitive fairly soonish.

Everything is ULTRA colorful to the point where it kinda is an eyesore (people who get a new ability or challenger know what I'm talking about).

Music is amazing. Hope you like Spanish guitar and trumpet stabs. ;-)

8/10 Would luchador again.

15267025.review:
First of all, the art is vibrant and makes good use of the luchador theme. The whole game is visually wonderful.

I didn’t care that much for the story (it’s a variant on the “saving the damsel in distress / getting the girl” theme), but the dialogue was pretty consistently funny and the characters are very dynamic.

In terms of gameplay, this is a really fun action platformer, with quite a lot of fighting going on. The combat moves are pretty simple, the game introduces them gradually, and they also serve as platforming moves, so it’s fairly easy to not get confused about them at any point.

I think it's great that you can add a 2nd player at any moment, especially since I found some of the big bosses to be quite hard to do alone.

Something that really disappointed me, though, was the need to complete the more challenging "optional" stuff to get the good ending. The other ending is incredibly lame and unsatisfactory. In my opinion, either you make the more challenging stuff necessary to even beat the game, or you make the fun ending available for people who choose not to do that extra stuff - otherwise, you're basically punishing  and insulting players who don't like completionist stuff, which is pretty much a jerk move.

Another (more minor) thing is that, even though you can choose to play the game as a female character, the game never actually acknowledges that by still calling you Juan and using male pronouns. Once again, it's like the game almost punishes that choice by just not taking any notice of it.

All in all, it's a good game and a lot of fun to play, but the apparent choices in play styles that are proposed are almost fake choices in that one option is punished and the other is the "good" choice.

15022839.review:
Pros:
- Funny humor, had me laughing a lot.
- Nice and intressting game mechanics, which makes combat fun.
- Fairly good lenght, could have been an hour or so shorter.

Cons:
- Music is bad, very repetative and annoying, you will most likely turn it off after about 30 minutes.
- Solving cliché and overused platforming puzzles isn't fun or challenging, just annoying.
- Nobody likes using the "switching between dimensions" mechanic to do these cliché platforming things, like dodging spikes or jumping between platforms in the different dimensions. I don't know why people keep putting this in games.
- When you die in a platformer, it should be because you misplayed and did something wrong because you aren't used to the game mechanics, not because you can't jump between walls in different dimension or that you don't have lightning reactions.
- Not having fall damage is understandable and can be good, but if you accidentally fall down to the start of the level, you shouldn't have to do it all over again.
- It's okay to have a final boss fight that is nearly  impossible to win, that will have you tearing out your hair in rage and will take you up towards 50 deaths before you even figure out how you are supposed to beat it, but then at least make the save after the cutscene so you don't have to sit through it every f***ing time.

All in all, it's not a great game. I want to like this game, I really do, because of it's humor and other upsides but a lot of the cons just really ruined it for me. Even though I at times had fun playing, I wouldn't want to play it ever again, nor would I recommend it to anyone.

Sorry devs. :(

After a Halloween party at my house, we tripped the electrical circuit after trying to plug in one too many space heaters at the same time. Sadly, after this incident, my computer would no longer boot Windows or even the Windows installation disc. Fortunately, I was able to salvage all my photos, documents, and important data. As my computer was getting to be fairly old (about six years), I took this opportunity to build a new PC.

I was trying to decide which game to try out for the first time on my new system, and was greeted by an advertisement in Steam letting me know that [i]Guacamelee![/i] was 50% off. I had heard great things about the game and hoped to play it some day, though I was under the impression that it was a PlayStation 3 exclusive. Seeing this pop up on Steam was a nice surprise, so I purchased it and started the download right away.

I'll just say that it was a wonderful experience. I think it struck the perfect balance for this style of game, where it is fairly linear overall but you can explore old locations to find plenty of secrets. New abilities are introduced at a good rate, and new enemies require you to use these powers. The combat was fun as well and I liked using Juan's wrestling skills to destroy opponents.

References to Nintendo characters and random memes made me chuckle. Nothing really made me laugh out loud, but I liked all these little touches.

Final comment: Chicken Suit is the best suit.

14713538.review:
Guacamelee is a fresh, very well made "Metroid-Vania" type of game.
Drikn Box Studio gave us a little gem.
The game is a sidescroller set in a fictional, yet charming, Mexico, and the whole game deals with the theme of "Luchadores" and mexican myths and legends regarding death and the afterworld.

As a "Metroid-Vania" the main character (Juan) has to travel across a variety of stages, fighting enemies and avoiding traps by platforming.
The thing that keeps the game fresh is the variety; the maps are very complex yet easy to navigate once you uncover the whole map, and the game perfectly balances its difficulty, starting very easy and getting harder closer to the end (yet not impossible).

Speaking of platforming, i have rarely seen such well made platforming sections in a very long time.
The developers really went crazy (in a good way) offering double jumps, moving plaftorms, flying powerups, portals, walljumps, wallslides, levers ecc..., and some puzzles are very challenging, yet very rewarding and well designed (note that most of these can be avoided if preferred).

The combat is an other thing that differenciates this game from the others; unlike other "Metroid-Vania" games here you have a very intuitive yet complex combo system, with the ability to throw enemies away and do some devastating chain attacks.
Enemies are well differenciated and you need personalised attacks to beat them.

The design of the game is great, featuring a charming 2D vector style; the characters are gorgeously animated and drawn, as well as the levels, each one colorful and very well drawn.
An other thing that makes this game original is its unique humor, the game is filled with an incredible amount of funny easter eggs regarding the whole "Internet/Memes" and "Videogames" worlds and the game offers the chance to use custom skins built by the community (available through Steam Workshop).

Guacamelee is a must-buy for everyone who likes 2D side scrolling games with a personal touch.
One of the best of its genre.

Pros:
- Charming Humor
- Fresh Design
- Complex Maps
- Amazing Platforming Action
- Deep and fun combat/combo System
- A ton of amazing easter eggs
- Varied puzzles
- Balanced Difficulty
- Balanced Lenght (Not too long, not too short)
- A lot of "developer made" and "Community made" custom skins

Cons:
- A couple of stages could have "dared" more in therms of visual design

To Keep In Mind:
- Some Orbs very very hard to get (Not necessary for the game completion)
- Inferno Challenges (endgame content) sometimes incredibly hard /frustrating
- Some achievements very hard to obtain (Not necessary for the game completion)
- Need a bit of grinding, if willing to collect all the treasure chests (Not necessary for the game completion)

14549528.review:
Guacamelee! is a really good platformer with a metroidvania style set in a world inspired by Mexican culture. This game is filled with comedy, and tons of references to other games, which add to the overall fun.

The gameplay is excellent, as a "Luchador" you make your way through punching: punching enemies, punching walls, punching chickens... As you progress, you get new abilities, which allow you to access new areas, by way of more, diverse ways of punching. There's also an ability that allows you to change between the world of the living and the world of the dead, and it's an interesting mechanics, as there will be sections where you find travelling back and forth between the worlds.

The environments themselves are really good: the world of the living is colourful, while the world of the dead has a darker tone.

The story is somewhat simple, but even then, it manages to be great. It starts with a normal man living a normal life, but, during the preparations for the "Día de los Muertos" festival, a powerful being raises from the world of the dead, and our hero must put on the Luchador mask, in order to save the day.

I recommend it.

14521887.review:
Este juego rebosa frescura por los cuatro costados. Es uno de esos juegos que no esperas gran cosa de él pero te llevas una grata sorpresa al jugarlo. La historia es genial, dentro de la sencillez, pero aún así genial. Pero dónde está el verdadero bien de este juego es en las mecánicas y en la jugabilidad, que es sublime. Mecánicas parecidas a Castlevania SOTN o Super Metroid, un gran mapeado que irás descubriendo a la vez que vas progresando y aumentando tus poderes, lleno de secretos y areas ocultas donde esperan tesoros. Algo corto pero totalmente rejugable. Un gran juego.

GRÁFICOS: Cumplen con su cometido, coloridos, muy buenas animaciones y todo muy claro. Quizá la estética es demasiado "cartoon", habrá quien no le guste pero le va muy bien al juego. 
Lo mejor: La fluidez de los movimientos y quizá los fondos de algunos mapeados, realmente hermosos.
Lo peor: Poca variedad de modelados y gran similitud entre los que hay. Se hecha en falta algo más de variedad.
NOTA: 8.0

SONIDO: Melodías frescas y divertidas, todas muy "mexicanas", y sonidos contundentes y variados. Nada del otro mundo pero le va muy bien al juego.
Lo mejor: Las melodías, sin dudarlo.
Lo peor: Algunos efectos repetitivos, como los golpes... nada reprochable.
NOTA: 7.7

JUGABILIDAD: El kit de la cuestión. Estamos aquí para hablar de esto. Avance lineal aunque con muchos secretillos para completarlo al 100%. La variedad de poderes y situaciones hacen que el desarrollo sea variado y fresco, aunque algunas peleas se hacen algo pesadas. Los jefes finales destacan por su diversidad y creatividad, de lo mejor del título. El personaje se mueve excelentemente y es fácil jugarlo aunque cuesta dominarlo, eso si, una vez lo dominas es un placer. 
Lo mejor: Los movimientos del personaje, que no son solo ataques, sino que además es una manera de avanzar. Los bosses son un placer jugarlos.
Lo peor: Algunas peleas se hacen pesadas y repetitivas, aunque tienen que estar. Algo corto.
NOTA: 9.0

Multijugador: El juego se puede completar jugando en cooperativo local, así que eso le añade algo de frescura, aunque le quita dificultad. Nada más que decir.

Conclusión, un gran juego del estilo Metroidvania que tanto se comenta por ahí, con sentido del humor y una historia interesante y divertida. Bonito final. Recomendable 100%

NOTA FINAL: 8.2

14159711.review:
Challenging platformer.

Guacamalee is a 'Metroid-styled, 2D- platformer developed by DrinkBox Studios. 

The plot of the game revolves around a farmer named Juan trying to to rescue the president's daughter from the clutches Carlos (the skeleton) who is goiing to sacrafice her in order to rule the world. In order to do so, Juan chases Carlos and defeats his lackies along the way.

Soundtrack is fantastic, giving off a mexican feel and draws you into the unique world. There is no voice acting with character dialogue through text. The sound effects for attacks are also good.

The graphics suit the game well. the colours are  vibrant and  not distracting, and do a good  job at instilling the mexican atmosphere in the game. Furthermore,  the characters and stages all have a mexican styled design to them which helps invoke the mexican atmosphere in the game.

Gameplay revolves around platforming and combat. The platforming in in this game varies between simple to challenging. Some platforms only require a few moves to get to such as simply jumping on them, while more challenging ones require precisely timed executions in order to reach. For the challenging platforming areas, it is difficult to get the precise key inputs through the keyboard as it can only detect a limited number of inputs at a time. I was forced to play with a 360 controller which made the experience more fluid and less frustrating. In combat you face a wide variety of foes including skeletons, dragons and  giants which either have melee or ranged attacks. The aim is mainly to unleash as many combos on them as possible to prevent them from attacking you. You have a varity of attacks which you can used to defeat your foes or to help reach platforms from side smash, uppercut and throws. You unlock more moves as you progress through the story. Furthermore, you can upgrade you character in variety of ways including increasing health, damage and spawn delay (by spending money). Furthermore, you can play the game via local co-op with a friend.


There are alot of references to other videogames such as nintendo characters Mario and Link (with mexican vibes to them). Furthermore, there are secrets hidden withen each area which allows you to unlock new costumes for your character. The different costumes each have a unique trait, such as increasing health/damage, which you can use to change how you tackle the combat. Plenty of other secrets lie in the game including secret stage which you can unlock by collecting enough money.

I highly recommend this game to people you love unique and challenging platformers.

Awesome game! First and foremost, I love the different elements of the game. The story I wouldn't call the best, but it also isn't a bad story. I'm indifferent about the story, but the characters and how some of them are presented are pretty hilarious at times. I love how the game is presented with the game's artistic appearance and how each area can be swapped in and out going from the "Land of the Dead" to the "Land of the Living". The Land of the Dead has a dark gloomy look. While the Land of the Living has this vibrant and cheerful look. Both of these have to be used through the game to get through certain areas. What may have been broken or destroyed in the living world, could still exist in the Land of the Dead. Which you can imagine how many different complexities this could add, and also how useful it could be. The music in this game is also a great addition. This game is very challenging at times, but you get a feeling of accomplishment after completing these areas. This game is a true platformer, one of the most difficult and challenging ones I've played in a while. It blends the elements of platforming and fighting into one game. The fighting actually has true fighting elements, such as combos. Some of these fighting moves can also be used as a platforming tool to reach different platforms. Which will be very useful during the game. The fighting for me is a big plus to this game. In many platformers, they lack good fighting mechanics. This game is a joy to play. I highly recommend it for any Platforming genre fan, or just a fan of good games.

9/10 Excellent!

13943059.review: This a metroidvania kind of game, but it feels short. As usual, you go through the different areas of a semi connected overworld and get powerups that let you return to places you had to pass up because they were blocked by some kind of obstacle that your new power can handle. It'ss also filled with easter eggs of some familiar AAA and indie games, but they get kind of inane pretty fast. The art and music are kind of stylized for the mexican theme but don't really feel that far from stock. There is plenty of straight up platforming which eventually scales to be pretty difficult, especially in areas hiding secret collectibles that aren't part of the main story. I found it to be of the "remember your combinations "variety instead of anything more exciting though..  Combat is more or less like a brawler, you're generally locked in and have to use optional combos, invulnerable dodges, and abilities (which have ending lag to prevent abuse) It isn't really as smart as a good old capcom game like final fight, and is kind of a step down from similiar hybird games like Elysian Tale and Muramasa as well. If you beat the game you get an optional hard mode, which has no differences bar one.. you get 2-4 hit points. I found this bad in cave story + and I was annoyed with it here as well. Memorization and muscle memory can get you through here as usual, especially with the kind of sluggish game speed. All in all, this is a game that has already been done.

13822910.review:
This game is aimed primarily at people who enjoy really intensely challenging, lightning speed beat-em-up combat and also really challenging precision platforming at the same time. You absolutely must enjoy both of those things or this game WILL increasingly piss you off as it goes on.

For me, I enjoy side-scrolling beat 'em ups and also enjoy platformers, but I am not the type of person who particularly enjoys intensely punishing difficulty in either one (maybe in a challenge mode, but not in the campaign). I picked up this game mainly because I had heard it had strong metroidvania elements, and I was very interested in exploring a mexi-metroid. The game started off super enjoyable and very much mexi-metroid, which I loved. But I started getting super frustrated at the game once I got to the Tule Tree, where the game first revealed its unwavering fetish for spamming dimension shift challenges in prolongued wall jumping segments. (If you think it will be over after the Tule Tree, you're wrong.) 

I stuck with it, though. It was infuriating, and I cursed a lot, but I stuck with it for a long time. I was disappointed that the metroidvania elements increasingly dwindle away and the game becomes more and more intensely focused on infuriating cage match challenges and infuriating platforming challenges where you have to execute a specific sequence of jump extenders (while dimension shifting ever other step, naturally), and the game just turns these up more, and more, and more as you advance. I kept feeling the frustration rise higher and higher as I progressed, but I kept on going.

I made it all the way to Javier Jaguar. I'm now quitting forever, because seriously: F**K THAT. Talk about a sudden and maddeningly huge difficulty spike. (Especially considering that the previous boss battle, Flame Face, is incredibly easy.) There comes a point where one experiences furious anger more than joy with a game. Javier Jaguar is the deal breaker for me and Gaucamelee. But I won't say that makes it a bad game. It is a beautiful game that I think was just not made for me. I recommend it to those of you who enjoy a game that invites you into its house with promises of cake and candy, but instead just holds you down and punches you in the balls over and over again, laughing and shouting surprise, until you cry.

13820351.review: The Guac! Guacamelee is a loving homage to metroidvania crammed with gaming references (you can find a dead Journey pilgrim if you're attentive), lovingly named super moves (derp) and crisp combo based combat. Framed by vengeance seeking luchadors and the Mexican land of the dead, you'll kick the crap out of skeletons through several contiguous zones, acquiring stuff every half hour or so to keep it interesting. In the end your combo suit should build from TMNT 2 three hit strikes to a ten hit juggle that suplexes everyone in the room. The art style and controls are clear and crisp, this is a technically perfect swing at this kind of game. The soundtrack is inessential and its maybe just a touch short (I would have liked another hour or so at the denoument) but it will definitely scratch the platformer itch. For bonus challenge, play with my busted Dualshock which randomly inputs L1, resulting in transformation to a harmless chicken mid-chasm or during a brawl.

13482710.review:
Guacamelee! is a platformer beat-em-up dimension-swap type game, taking place somewhere in Mexico. Your game starst out in the house of Juan, a peaceful farmer, and get called into your village by the priest, who informs you your childhood friend/love interest has arrived for a festival. You go to help her pick up chairs or something, but find out Carlos Calaca and his henchmen have taken her for whatever they need her for. You try to put up a fight but he kills you. Finding yourself in the land of the dead, you discover a lochador mask and put it on, returning to the normal world with the newfound power of the luchador, ready to save your girlfriend by fighting skeletons, swapping dimensions, and learning new tricks from a... goat... thing. 
The gameplay is very fun, and although it is a platformer with lots of puzzles, it also smoothly incorporates combat within that. Dimension swapping is the main puzzle of the game, and since both worlds have different walls, blocks, and enemies, you will swap between the two frequently. I do have to say that I consider myself a veteran platformer gamer and I found some optional portions of the game incredibly aggravating, to the point where I had to quit playing and take a break. It's very rhythmic because of the dimension swap, and often takes several times to do it correctly. 
The art is fantastic. The cartoon-y simple characters look very good, and the enemies are excellent as well. I also liked the art within the game. Several billlboards are in the larger towns and are full of video game references, which I thought was cool. 
The music can get repetitive, especially if you are stuck on one part. It does have two different versions of the same song for different dimensions however, which I liked. 
The story itself is somewhat lacking, but what they do have is pretty good. It's not really about the story, and I wasn't following the events, but they had a bit of dialogue and I understood what was going on. 

Overall, I'd give the game a 9/10. It's a good challenge for anyone who wants to try, and is one of those games that is very fun to try and "complete".

13464043.review: Guacamelee is gorgeous and fun metroidvania game. Reminds me somewhat of Outland, with the switching between light and dark worlds, but Guacamelee has less of the bullet hell and more of the titular melee action. I'm not a huge fan of backtracking, but the world is laid out so smartly that even as it expands, your accumulating powers allow you to traverse the world more and more rapidly. Combat is challenging, but fair. Cetain fight setups felt cheap and unfair on first attempt, but after some careful observation and thought (and a few deaths), they were actually quite reasonable. Checkpoints are relatively generous, and placed in all the spots you'd want them. The boss fight thankfully actually uses the same skills honed during the rest of the game, rather than throwing in something out of left field. All in all, a total pleasure.
